description: Federal Reserve officials held off on cutting interest rates this week because they wanted to see slightly more data to feel confident that inflation is truly coming under control. While that approach is cautious when it comes to price increases, Friday’s employment report underscored that it might be a risky one when it comes to the job market.

title: Can Kamala Harris Rebuild the Democratic Coalition?
description: With a little over three months until the presidential election, Kamala Harris inherited a Democratic coalition that was badly frayed.

title: At a Mountain Retreat, Wine, Lamb Kebabs and Lots of Climate Talk
description: A few days ago, at an ornate hilltop hotel in Azerbaijan’s wine country with panoramic views of the Caucasus foothills, the world’s top climate diplomats debated how to marshal whopping amounts of money to fight global warming and compensate poor and vulnerable countries that suffer its worst effects.

title: Is Tim Walz the Midwestern Dad Democrats Need?
description: Update: This interview was published Friday, Aug. 2. On Tuesday, Aug. 6, Kamala Harris announced that Tim Walz will be her running mate.

title: Champagne, Soft Piano and No Lines: Luxe Life at the Olympics
description: Getting to the Olympics equestrian arena at Versailles — a multihour metro, train and bus extravaganza culminating in a mile-long trek down a dusty thoroughfare — is so arduous and enervating that it almost qualifies as an athletic achievement in itself.

title: Mark Kelly Is a Different Kind of Democrat
description: Any discussion of Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, who is on Kamala Harris’s shortlist of vice-presidential picks, invariably includes the phrase “former NASA astronaut.” He flew four Space Shuttle missions — two as commander — the desideratum of a child’s imagining of a future career and a killer résumé line for anyone running for public office.

title: Russia Released 16 Prisoners. Hundreds of Others Were Left Behind.
description: For the 16 people released from Russian captivity on Thursday in a landmark prisoner swap, the exchange brought a moment of momentous relief. But many others were left behind.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Aug. 2, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Don’t Listen to the Right. The Kamalanomenon Is Real.
description: Tracy Nailor, a 56-year-old Atlanta pediatrician, wasn’t particularly impressed with Kamala Harris when she first ran for president. “I think I succumbed to the narrative about her,” she said. She thought Harris wasn’t experienced or accomplished enough to merit the Democratic nomination. “I just didn’t know enough,” she said. “I didn’t do my homework.” Instead of Harris, she supported the trusted, familiar Joe Biden in the last election.

title: At 97, This Conductor Is Modest and Extraordinary
description: If you’ve been reading news about the U.S. presidential election, you might be forgiven for thinking that age has something to do with ability.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the season finale of “House of the Dragon.”

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Susan Casey, Yunte Huang, Caleb Azumah Nelson and more.

title: Navalny Couldn’t Be Freed Until Gershkovich Was Kidnapped. Gershkovich Couldn’t Be Freed Until Navalny Was Dead.
description: A few days ago, Russian political prisoners started vanishing from their prison colonies: Their lawyers would come to see them only to be told their clients were no longer there. The disappearance of an inmate is often bad news — it can mean a move to a more remote colony, illness or death. But as the number of “missing” prisoners grew, in the Russian dissident community a mounting sense of anticipation replaced the concern. “A trade,” a prominent Russian in exile posted on his Facebook page, without bothering to explain the reference. “Definitely a trade,” posted a young Russian activist in exile, a day later. “I am hopeful and I’m afraid to say the word,” posted another.

title: The Zoom Election, Google DeepMind’s Math Olympiad and HatGPT Olympics Edition
description: This week, with hundreds of thousands of people joining online political rallies for Kamala Harris, we discuss whether 2024 is suddenly becoming the Zoom election, and what that means for both parties’ political organizing. Then, Pushmeet Kohli, a computer scientist at Google DeepMind, joins us for a conversation about how his team’s new A.I. models just hit a silver medal score on the International Mathematical Olympiad exam. And finally, it’s time for a new round of HatGPT! This time, it’s a special Olympics tech edition.

title: 5 Ways to Make Friends (Without Joining a Book Club)
description: My sister Dinah recently told me about an unusual way that she made friends after her divorce. Her youngest was starting her college search, and Dinah was nostalgic for when her children were small. So she started babysitting for a family with toddlers.

title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Directed by Carlos Saldanha, this adaptation of the children's book of the same name follows Harold (Zachary Levi) with the magical purple crayon that brings his drawings to life as he encounters adulthood and the real world.

title: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $310 Million in July, More Than Double Trump’s Haul
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign survived a brutal few weeks of fund-raising in July to bounce back so dramatically before the end of the month that she more than doubled the amount of money raised by former President Donald J. Trump, her campaign announced on Friday.

title: The Gaza Conflict Enters ‘Uncharted Territory’
description: “I don’t think war is inevitable,” Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Wednesday, after senior leaders of Hezbollah and Hamas were killed in pinpoint attacks in a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon, and Tehran. He was right; war is never inevitable until it breaks out. But suddenly the possibility of an all-in conflict of unpredictable breadth between Israel and its Iran-backed enemies, into which the United States would most likely be drawn, had become a dangerous possibility.

title: Long After Surviving the Nazis, They Use A.I. to Remind the World
description: The Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan, like other institutions that memorialize the Holocaust, has long relied on survivors to provide firsthand accounts of the cruelties imposed by the Nazis and the various paths people took to endure.

title: Joe Biden Issues a Stinging Dissent
description: The Supreme Court is caught in a crisis of its own making.

title: In Aspen, a New Art Fair Follows the Money
description: A down art market? Depressed dealers? Fatigued buyers?

title: A One-Man Team’s 11-Second Olympics
description: As his nation’s lone athlete at the Paris Olympics, Winzar Kakiouea carried an additional burden: Most people have no idea that his country is a country.

title: Why Some Young People in China Pretend to Be Birds
description: To become a bird, pull an oversize T-shirt over your arms and torso. Hide your legs. Let your hands stick out like claws and your empty sleeves flap like wings.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,141, Saturday, August 3, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 419, August 3, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: A Major Prisoner Exchange, and U.S. Says Venezuelan Opposition Won
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The Secret Succession Fight That Will Determine the Future of Fox News
description: For years, Rupert Murdoch seemed content to let his children battle it out for control of his conservative media empire once he’s gone.Jim Rutenberg, who writes about media and politics for The Times, discusses how a secret change to that plan by Mr. Murdoch touched off an ugly family squabble that could influence how much of the world sees the news.

title: What to See at the Edinburgh Fringe
description: Each summer, artists and audience members from across the globe decamp to Scotland for the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the world’s largest performing arts event. This year, from Aug. 2 through 26, the city will be repurposed into a labyrinth of makeshift theaters, in dingy rooms above pubs, hotel conference rooms and university lecture theaters.

title: The Harris Electorate
description: Kamala Harris inherited a Democratic coalition that was badly frayed. In polls, young, Black and Hispanic voters abandoned President Biden in droves. And for the first time in years, more Americans said they leaned Republican than Democratic.

title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: Sandy Cheeks, the high-energy Texan squirrel from the SpongeBob SquarePants universe, gets to save the day in this new, bizarro movie that incorporates both live action and animation. Packed into 90 minutes are musical numbers, thick-as-molasses Southern accents and Wanda Sykes as an evil blue-haired C.E.O. named Sue.

title: Hard Landing Concerns Jolt Global Markets
description: Global markets are a blur of red on Friday as investors fret that the U.S. economy is heading for a slowdown.

title: Chevron, in Snub to California, Will Move Its Headquarters to Houston
description: Chevron, the second-largest U.S. oil company, is moving its headquarters to Houston from California, formalizing a long-expected breakup with a state that has pushed aggressively to address climate change.

title: U.S. to Send More Combat Aircraft and Warships to Middle East, Officials Say
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Friday ordered additional combat aircraft and missile-shooting warships to the Middle East in response to threats from Iran and its proxies in Gaza, Lebanon and Yemen to attack Israel in the coming days to avenge the death of Ismail Haniyeh, the Pentagon said.

title: Why You Should Be Taking a Hard Look at Your Investments Right Now
description: All eyes were on the Federal Reserve this past week, or so several market analysts solemnly said. This was true even though the Fed essentially did nothing in its latest meeting but hold interest rates high to fight inflation, just as it has done for many months.

title: A Mortgage Alternative for Lower-Priced Homes Comes With Risks
description: With traditional mortgages for lower-priced homes hard to get, some home buyers are turning to riskier alternatives, like seller-financed loans known as “land contracts” that don’t involve a bank.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: Welcome to the ninth week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

title: Convicted Assassin Is a Russian Security Agent, Kremlin Acknowledges
description: The convicted assassin who was the linchpin of the biggest prisoner swap in decades is a member of the most powerful security agency in Russia, the Kremlin acknowledged on Friday, and had served in a special unit with some agents who now guard President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Tropical Storm Debby Forms Over Gulf of Mexico, Bringing Flooding Threat
description: Read updated coverage of Tropical Storm Debby.

title: As the World Looks Elsewhere, Famine Descends on Darfur
description: Sudan has in this century endured genocide, civil war and partition, and now its crisis has worsened. Famine has officially been declared in part of the Darfur region in western Sudan.

title: Olympic Officials Defend Fighters’ Eligibility in Women’s Boxing Controversy
description: Lin Yu-ting strode toward the boxing ring on Friday fully aware that she was walking straight into a swirling controversy that has turned the Paris Olympics into a forum for a fierce debate about biology, gender and fairness in women’s sports.

title: Appeals Court Further Narrows Voting Rights Act’s Scope
description: A federal appeals court further narrowed the scope of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, ruling that members of separate minority groups cannot join together to claim that a political map has been drawn to dilute their voting power.

title: Families of Hostages Despair as Hopes for Imminent Peace Deal Fade
description: Jonathan Dekel-Chen, whose son Sagui is held hostage by Hamas in Gaza, said he left a meeting last week with President Biden more optimistic than he had felt in months that a deal to free his son could be close.

title: A Tomato Sandwich That’s Very Tomato
description: Good morning. The tomatoes are perfect right now where I stay, dense with juice, sweet with just a hint of acidity, super robust. They take to salt nicely. They call for herbs, sometimes for cheese. I can use a half dozen or more over the course of the weekend, and doing so makes me feel as if I live in Southern California, driving to buy them in a restored Cabriolet (white, with white interior, vanity plates reading TOM8TO).

title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: The rom-com/sci-fi subgenre is on a roll. For a nice date night double bill, you could do worse than pairing the very funny “Molli and Max in the Future” with this bittersweet take on dating and relationships. The Mexican director Enrique Vázquez’s debut feature is set in a near-future when common wisdom holds that relationships last four years before souring. Whether or not couples still get along by that point, they split and people look for another partner. Getting ready to embark on a new contract, as relationships are now called, Fran (Regina Blandón) makes up answers to her matchmaking questionnaire, which messes up the algorithm. She ends up being paired with the sweetly dorky Roque (Leonardo Ortizgris), even though they don’t seem to share much. But maybe love is not based on perfect sync, after all, and maybe it can last longer than four years. Or can it?

title: Billie Eilish Joins Charli XCX’s Brat Summer, and 10 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: Jolted by Soft Jobs Report, Stocks Tumble to End a Turbulent Week
description: Wall Street was jolted by rising economic uncertainty on Friday, and stocks skidded, capping off a turbulent week with a sharp decline.

title: Olympic Champion Simone Biles Posted on Social Media That She Loves her ‘Black Job’
description: Simone Biles, who catapulted herself to a sixth gold medal and ninth overall medal in her storied Olympic career with a victory in the women’s all-around gymnastics competition Thursday, seemed to take a not-so-subtle dig at Donald J. Trump on social media.

title: Benjamin Luxon, Rich Baritone Thwarted by Hearing Loss, Dies at 87
description: Benjamin Luxon, a warm-voiced British baritone who was admired for his singing of German and British song and his robust opera performances, but whose flourishing career was cut short by encroaching deafness, died on July 25 at his home in Sandisfield, Mass. He was 87.

title: The U.K. Riots Were Fomented Online. Will Social Media Companies Act?
description: Standing in front of a lectern on Thursday, his voice at times taut with anger, Britain’s prime minister announced a crackdown on what he called the “gangs of thugs” who instigated violent unrest in several towns this week.

title: The Big Number: 5.25%
description: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday left interest rates unchanged at 5.25 percent, keeping rates at their highest level in two decades.

title: Manfred Kirchheimer, ‘Indispensable’ New York Filmmaker, Dies at 93
description: Manfred Kirchheimer, a filmmaker who was drawn to stickball, jazz, subway graffiti, gargoyles on old buildings and the memories of aging immigrants, and who after decades of slowpoke perfectionism earned a reputation as a master of nonfiction cinema, died on July 16 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Netanyahu, Defiant, Appears to Have Gone Rogue, Risking a Regional War
description: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

title: ‘Trap’ Review: Pop Goes the Thriller
description: “Dad, this is the literally the best day of my life,” the teenager Riley (Ariel Donoghue) beams to her doting father, Cooper (Josh Hartnett), in the opening minutes of M. Night Shyamalan’s “Trap.” That feeling won’t last — but for the first half of this mischievous thriller, we’re also having fun.

title: See Where Countersnipers Could Have Stopped the Trump Rally Gunman
description: Where countersnipers were stationed — and where they were not — has emerged as a point of contention in assessing lapses that failed to prevent an assassination attempt.

title: Icon or Eyesore? Palm Springs to Move Divisive Marilyn Monroe Statue
description: It was a sweltering day in Palm Springs, and a few intrepid tourists braved the unforgiving sun to snap selfies at the stilettoed feet of a colossal Marilyn Monroe, her white dress seeming to billow up in the hot dry wind.

title: Sarah Jessica Parker on Her Life in Publishing
description: Sarah Jessica Parker has been a familiar presence on TV, movie screens and Broadway stages for five decades. But since 2016 she has also been a force in the book world, initially at the helm of the fiction imprint SJP for Hogarth and for the past two years with SJP Lit, an imprint at the independent publisher Zando.

title: Protesting Hunger, Nigerians Warn, ‘Life Cannot Continue Like This’
description: Nigerians struggling to afford food and earn a living have taken to the streets in nationwide protests that have already left at least 13 people killed, according to Amnesty International.

title: Who’s Afraid of Being Black? Not Kamala, Beyoncé or Kendrick.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t take the race bait.

title: An Autocrat’s Tool Backfires in Venezuela
description: It is common for autocrats to hold elections. As I’ve written before, winning an election can allow an autocratic leader to claim a popular mandate and to demonstrate to the military and to the political elite that the government’s hold on power is strong enough to make loyalty their safest bet.

title: Senior U.S. Diplomat Will Lead Kamala Harris’s Running Mate’s Team
description: Elizabeth M. Allen, a veteran diplomat and political operative, is stepping down from her position as the U.S. under secretary of state for public diplomacy to take on a senior role in Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign.

title: JD Vance Pioneered ‘New Right’ Economics. Trump May Not Embrace It.
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, is a pioneer in what friends and critics alike call a new form of Republican economic thinking. It’s a vision to steer the economy toward advancing socially conservative goals, even when those policies defy conservative orthodoxy about government intervention in private markets.

title: Harris Has Votes Needed to Be Democrats’ Nominee, D.N.C. Says
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has won enough delegates to secure the Democratic Party’s nomination, the Democratic National Committee said on Friday, setting up Ms. Harris to become the first Black woman and person of South Asian heritage to earn the top spot on a major political ticket for president.

title: U.S. Sues TikTok Over Child Privacy Violations
description: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday, accusing it of illegally collecting children’s data and escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app.

title: Police Investigate Death Threats Against Olympics Opening Ceremony Director
description: The Paris police are investigating death threats and online harassment targeting Thomas Jolly, the Olympic opening ceremony’s artistic director, the Paris prosecutor’s office said on Friday.

title: Read the lawsuit
description: The Justice Department said in its legal filing that TikTok had violated a leading child privacy law.

title: The Olympics’ No. 1 Fan
description: Some time on Monday night, his head doubtless heavy with sorrow, Antoine Griezmann returned to Madrid. He had stayed away as long as possible, but he was due for his first training session with Atlético Madrid on Tuesday morning. The European soccer season, long and arduous, hangs on the horizon. Summer, for him, had ended. It was time to return to work.

title: Not One of Us: Trump Uses Old Tactic to Sow Suspicion About Harris
description: She is not one of us.

title: Alan Garber Will Stay On as Harvard’s President
description: Harvard University named Alan M. Garber as its president on Friday, a bid for stability after months of harsh public scrutiny and immense private turmoil.

title: Is It Weird to Care About the Birthrate?
description: JD Vance is one of the first important politicians in the United States to directly take up one of the preoccupations of this newsletter — the ongoing collapse of birthrates across the developed world and the grim consequences of an aging, childless future — and it’s fair to say it isn’t going well so far. Not just his dig at “childless cat ladies” but also his past support for a system where parents cast votes on behalf of their children have been fodder for the Democratic Party’s newfound narrative about the Trump-Vance ticket: that it’s creepy, bizarre, weird.

title: Untitled (The Playlist)
description: Today, Jack White released a new solo album named “No Name,” joining the ranks of the many artists throughout history who have finished a piece of music and, confronted with the challenge of giving it an all-encompassing title, simply shrugged and said, “I’d rather not.” Elliott Smith, for example, had a whole numbered series of “No Name” songs, while the Breeders called their 2002 album “Title TK,” publishing shorthand for “to come later.” The rapper Noname has confused things further, cheekily titling a recent song “Namesake.” The mind boggles.

title: How Does Your State Make Electricity?
description: There’s been a big shift in how America produces power. Each state has its own story.

title: Reflections About the Prisoner Swap
description: To the Editor:

title: Delaware Judge Questions Tesla About Vote on Elon Musk’s Tesla Pay
description: A Delaware judge on Friday questioned lawyers for Tesla about why the company asked shareholders to vote on a $55 billion pay package for its chief executive, Elon Musk, after she had struck it down in January.

title: In Iceland, a Feminist Inspired by the Country’s History Is the New President
description: Seven-year-old Halla Tómasdóttir was confused on her mother’s birthday in 1975. Her mother and aunts weren’t in the kitchen as usual, instead directing their husbands and brothers to do the work. That was because women were taking the day off to demonstrate their value to society amid Iceland’s first national women’s strike.

title: Kamala Harris Hires Top Obama Advisers, Building Out Campaign
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, who formally won enough delegates to secure the Democratic Party nomination on Friday, is remaking a campaign hierarchy originally built to re-elect President Biden by adding several new advisers to the top ranks of her staff, including David Plouffe, who managed Barack Obama’s first presidential run.

title: Ippon! Teddy Riner thrills home crowd to grab Olympic gold in judo.
description: The French judoka Teddy Riner is 6-foot-8, weighs 300(ish) pounds and once went a very, very, very, very, very, very, very (very) long time without losing, a stretch of supremacy that launched him into a realm of renown in France generally occupied by soccer stars, fashion doyennes and philosophers.

title: Peter C. Theisinger, 78, Dies; Led Mars Rover Missions for NASA
description: Growing up in California, Peter C. Theisinger assembled model airplanes, tinkered with electronic hobby kits and operated a ham radio set. But when it came to building anything bigger than a bread box, even as an adult, he recalled, “I was never mechanical, never tried to fix my car.”

title: Justin Timberlake, on Tour, Beams Into Sag Harbor to Plead Not Guilty
description: Justin Timberlake’s world tour detoured to Sag Harbor, N.Y., on Friday, when a judge suspended his driving privileges in New York while he fights a drunken-driving charge.

title: Haunting Image: First Photo Released of C.I.A. Prisoner at Black Site
description: For years, defense lawyers in the Guantánamo cases have spoken of reviewing disturbing government photos of the prisoners being held by the C.I.A. in the Bush administration’s secret overseas prison, the black sites. But they were marked classified, and the world was not allowed to see them. Until now.

title: Joe Manchin Is Forcing an Agonizing Trade-Off on Climate Change
description: This week Senator Joe Manchin, independent from West Virginia, called a committee vote on a bill to speed up approval of energy projects that puts environmentalists in a tough spot. It gives them something they badly want, along with something they strongly oppose.

title: Was I Wrong to Reveal That My Novel Was Inspired by an Adulterous Friend?
description: Two decades ago, while raising a child in a small town, my husband and I became close to two other families with children the same age as ours. We socialized frequently, both on and off the playground. Then it came to light that, for more than a year, one of the husbands had been having an affair with the wife of the other, and our chummy sextuplet was torn asunder.

title: Tech Bosses Preach Patience as They Spend and Spend on A.I.
description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, started 2023 by declaring it the “year of efficiency.” Like several of its big tech peers, Meta cut jobs and mothballed expansion plans.

title: A ‘Love Activist’ D.J. Opened the Olympics. Then Came a Wave of Hate.
description: The Paris Olympics opening ceremony made the French D.J. Barbara Butch famous and infamous around the world. Already known in France as an outspoken lesbian and activist for fat people, Butch — her stage name, of course — appeared with a crown and her mixing board in one of the last scenes, called “Festivity.”

title: The Court Filing
description: The photo was declassified with the release of a 2019 filing by Ammar al-Baluchi’s legal team.

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Sentenced to Life Plus 20 Years for Sexually Abusing Child
description: A former F.B.I. agent turned Alabama state trooper who was convicted of sexually abusing an 11-year-old girl over several years was sentenced on Thursday to life plus 20 years in prison.

title: Russian Dissident Says He Was Traded Against His Will in Inmate Swap
description: Ilya Yashin, one of the Russian dissidents traded to the West in Thursday’s prisoner exchange for a group of Russian agents, cybercriminals and an assassin, said on Friday that he did not want his freedom if it meant leaving his country.

title: How to Watch the Summer Olympics in 4K
description: You can watch those handsprings in ultra high definition.

title: Does Anyone Have Leverage Over Nicolás Maduro?
description: The message delivered Thursday night was blunt: The United States recognized Venezuela’s opposition presidential candidate as the winner in Sunday’s election and dismissed a declaration by election officials that the country’s autocrat, President Nicolás Maduro, had won.

title: Sha’Carri Richardson Is Ready for Her Moment
description: Sha’Carri Richardson is only interested in moving in one direction: forward. Her preference is to do so very, very quickly.

title: Death of Black Man at Milwaukee Hyatt Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a Black man who was held down by security guards outside a Milwaukee hotel has been ruled a homicide as prosecutors review possible murder charges against four people in connection with his death.

title: It’s official: Léon Marchand owns the pool after winning his fourth gold medal.
description: Léon Marchand walked out to an adoring audience before his final individual event of these Olympics on Friday night. He’d already won them over — the home crowd, the city of Paris, the country of France — but he had another race to win.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 3, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: Agency Votes to Replace Official Accused of Rushing Start of Seabed Mining
description: The international agency charged with regulating seabed mining worldwide voted on Friday to replace its top executive, after accusations that the British lawyer running the agency was too closely aligned with the mining industry.

title: Harris Won Enough Votes to Be the Democratic Nominee
description: The Democratic National Committee announced today that Vice President Kamala Harris had secured enough delegates to clinch the Democratic Party’s nomination for president. She will be the first Black woman and person of South Asian heritage to earn the top spot on a major party’s ticket.

title: Germany Grapples With ‘Difficult Decision’ in Prisoner Swap
description: The convicted Russian killer bounded off a plane in Moscow on Thursday, hours after Germany freed him in a wide-ranging prison exchange with Russia. President Vladimir V. Putin hugged him on the tarmac, in a hero’s welcome.

title: Hamas Leader’s Funeral Comes Amid Fears His Killing May Block Cease-Fire Deal
description: Thousands packed Qatar’s largest mosque on Friday for the funeral of Ismail Haniyeh, Hamas’s political leader, hours after President Biden said his killing could hurt the monthslong effort to negotiate a cease-fire in Gaza.

title: Yvonne Furneaux, Cosmopolitan Actress in ‘La Dolce Vita,’ Dies at 98
description: Yvonne Furneaux, a French-born English actress known for her icy beauty and continental air who brought jet-setting panache to critically acclaimed films like Federico Fellini’s “La Dolce Vita” and Roman Polanski’s “Repulsion,” died on July 5 at her home in North Hampton, N.H. She was 98.

title: Highlights From the 2024 Paris Olympics
description: See our photographers’ best images from the Summer Games.

title: The Veepstakes (Pennsylvania’s Version)
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s supersonic veep search is in its final stages, and she heads into the weekend with much to consider before she announces her choice.

title: Prisoner Deals Stoke Fears of Perverse ‘Incentive’ to Grab Americans
description: Behind the jubilation over the latest release of Americans unjustly imprisoned abroad are growing concerns that a new era of hostage diplomacy has emerged, with U.S. adversaries concluding that it pays to arrest innocent Americans and trade them for convicted smugglers, hackers, spies — and even killers.

title: Secret Service Chief Admits Lack of Certainty on Sniper Locations at Trump Rally
description: The Secret Service’s acting director acknowledged on Friday that when he told congressional investigators that local law enforcement snipers should have been able to see the gunman who shot former President Donald J. Trump at a rally, he did not have details from the snipers themselves on their locations.

title: Judge Awards Schiele Drawing to Heirs of Merchant Killed by the Nazis
description: For three weeks in May a judge in Rochester, N.Y., heard evidence meant to solve the mystery of who really owns a drawing of a smiling woman by the Austrian artist Egon Schiele.

title: How Katie Ledecky Won the Most Medals of Any U.S. Female Olympian
description: Katie Ledecky now stands alone as the most decorated female American Olympian, in any sport, with 13 medals. And she still has one more race to swim in France. Jenny Vrentas, a New York Times reporter covering sports, explains how Ledecky reached this milestone.

title: What’s Uniting, and Dividing, Native Voters in Arizona
description: A usually solidly Democratic vote, Native American voters across the state say they feel increasingly left out of the conversation and are looking for change.

title: Passenger Who Tried to Open Cockpit and Exit Door Gets 19 Months in Prison
description: A California man who tried to intimidate flight attendants on an American Airlines flight using plastic silverware from a service cart and a glass champagne bottle, and then tried unsuccessfully to open an exit door and the cockpit, was sentenced on Wednesday to 19 months in prison.

title: Alongside the Trump-Russia Inquiry, a Lesser-Known Look at Egyptian Influence
description: In the summer of 2017, as the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III was starting his investigation, his agents and prosecutors were chasing potentially explosive allegations about foreign influence over Donald J. Trump and his campaign.

title: Shapiro’s College-Era Criticism of Palestinians Draws Fresh Scrutiny
description: Gov. Josh Shapiro, Democrat of Pennsylvania, wrote in his college newspaper three decades ago that Palestinians were “too battle-minded” to achieve a two-state solution in the Middle East, prompting criticism as Vice President Kamala Harris considers him to be her running mate.

title: Aerosmith Retires From Touring, Citing Steven Tyler’s Vocal Injury
description: Aerosmith, the venerated American hard rock band whose hit records like “Dream On” have reverberated across the airwaves and in sweaty sold-out venues around the world for more than half a century, announced Friday that it was retiring from the tour stage, citing a permanent vocal injury to its star frontman, Steven Tyler.

title: Defense Secretary Revokes Plea Deal for Accused Sept. 11 Plotters
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Friday overruled the overseer of the war court at Guantánamo Bay and revoked a plea agreement reached earlier this week with the accused mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and two alleged accomplices.

title: Meta in Talks to Use Voices of Judi Dench, Awkwafina and Others for A.I.
description: Meta is in discussions with Awkwafina, Judi Dench and other actors and influencers for the right to incorporate their voices into a digital assistant product called MetaAI, according to three people with knowledge of the talks, as the company pushes to build more products that feature artificial intelligence.

title: Maui Wildfire Plaintiffs Reach $4 Billion Settlement as Anniversary Nears
description: Nearly a year after a ferocious wildfire on Maui killed 102 people and leveled the historic town of Lahaina, Hawaii’s largest utility has agreed to pay the largest share of a legal settlement totaling just over $4 billion and compensating more than 10,000 homeowners, businesses and other plaintiffs.

title: Foggy
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Rich Norris, a fixture in the crossword community who used to edit the crossword at The Los Angeles Times, is now making a constructing comeback for The New York Times. This is his second Saturday grid of 2024, but his 120th overall; the other 118 puzzles ran between 1994 and 2008. (Thanks to technology, you can solve all of them online, but they predate the Wordplay column, so no hints from us!)

title: To Lam Confirmed as Vietnam’s Top Leader Until at Least 2026
description: President To Lam of Vietnam, best known for implementing a sweeping anticorruption drive, will become the country’s next Communist Party general secretary, the government’s Politburo announced on Saturday.

title: Iran Arrests Dozens in Search for Suspects in Killing of Hamas Leader
description: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

title: Marcell Jacobs Has Waited a Long Time to Prove the Doubters Wrong
description: The strict security protocols governing the movements of President Sergio Mattarella of Italy dictate that he is not permitted to appear in the same location repeatedly. He is, in this respect and probably this respect alone, like lightning: He is not supposed to strike twice.

title: Bombs Rain Down in Myanmar as Junta Evades Sanctions to Buy Jet Fuel
description: The family ducked for cover when junta jets roared over their home in central Myanmar. U Har San and his wife crawled under a table, and their daughter, eight months pregnant, hid under a bed. Bombs rained down, he said, even though no rebel fighters were in their village.

title: Deputy Killed and Two Others Wounded in Ambush Shooting in Florida, Sheriff Says
description: A sheriff’s deputy was killed and two other deputies were wounded in what officials described as an ambush shooting inside a Florida home on Friday night.

title: Trump Cancels a Debate With Harris on ABC News and Pitches One With Fox News Instead
description: Former President Donald J. Trump declared late on Friday that he was dropping out of an ABC News debate scheduled for Sept. 10 and presented a counterproposal to Vice President Kamala Harris, his presumptive opponent, to face off on Fox News six days earlier.

title: Corrections: Aug. 3, 2024
description: A Critic’s Notebook article on Thursday about the relationship between art and sport at the Cultural Olympiad described incorrectly when the cultural component of the Olympics began. The Olympics have long featured cultural events, but that component was not officially called the Cultural Olympiad until 1992.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Ten Seconds, One-Man Team Could Be Done
description: “I like the 100 meters because it is short.”

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: How a ‘Dirty Gospel’ Minister Spends His Sundays
description: When most people picture a minister, Vince Anderson is not who comes to mind.

title: Equestrian Is Having an Uncomfortable Moment. Its Olympic Horses Are Not.
description: For most of the athletes at the Paris Olympics, the accommodations are to be endured, rather than enjoyed. In the name of sustainability, the beds at the Olympic Village feature cardboard frames and inflatable mattresses. The bathrooms are communal. To the horror of the French, the British have even complained about the food.

title: A Brooklyn Enclave’s Uneasy Peace With 4,000 New Migrant Neighbors
description: Last summer, as New York City was in the throes of a migrant influx from the southern border, residents near the Brooklyn Navy Yard began to notice a growing number of African and Latin American migrants milling around the neighborhood’s parks and sidewalks.

title: Inside the ‘Shakespearean Drama’ of the Murdoch Family
description: When Rupert Murdoch married for the fifth time this past June, the wedding was absent a few notable guests: three of his four eldest children, James, Elisabeth and Prudence.

title: Street Sheds Transformed New York City Dining. Many Will Soon Disappear.
description: More than four years after the coronavirus upended life in New York City, some of the most visible vestiges of the pandemic — outdoor dining structures erected outside thousands of restaurants — are facing a deadline that could see many of them razed.

title: The Pentagon promises to help defend Israel.
description: Israel was bracing for retaliatory attacks from Iran and its proxies in the aftermath of a top Hamas leader’s assassination as additional American combat aircraft and missile-shooting warships were being dispatched to the region.

title: Can Harris Build Momentum Among South Asian Voters in Georgia?
description: In Georgia, a critical swing state President Biden won by less than 12,000 votes in 2020, Kamala Harris’ political identity has prompted renewed interest among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.

title: The Retirement Home for N.F.L. Players That Never Was
description: In 2014, the Pro Football Hall of Fame announced plans for a $500 million development on its campus in Canton, Ohio. Included in the renderings was a senior care facility called Legends Landing. It was intended to serve aging N.F.L. retirees, including those with cognitive diseases that researchers have associated with the repeated hits to the head many football players take during their careers.

title: Amid Heavy Industry, Canada’s Newest (and Tiniest) National Park
description: The beach is more about broken glass from generations of illicit parties than sand. The roar and squeal of a nearby railway locomotive compete with the birdsong. The wind carries a sweet chemical scent from a cooking oil processing plant to the west.

title: Ashley Park Wants to Laugh (or Cry) With You at the Theater
description: Ashley Park has heard the criticism of “Emily in Paris.” The costumes can be garish. (Bucket hats? In the office?!) The characters can be cartoonish. The biggest worry for Emily, the protagonist, is often whether to cut trauma bangs or what outré dress to wear next.

title: So, Human Resources Is Making You Miserable?
description: Show of hands: Who’s fed up with human resources?

title: Will A.I. Kill Meaningless Jobs?
description: When Brad Wang started his first job in the tech industry, right after college, he marveled at the way Silicon Valley had turned the drudgery of the workplace into a sumptuousness of game rooms, nap pods and leafy hiking trails. This is what it must have felt like to be a guest showing up for a party at Jay Gatsby’s house, Mr. Wang thought.

title: A Prescription for Physicians: Listen to the Patient’s Story
description: One of the riveting tales in “Telltale Hearts,” a new memoir, is about the author’s great-uncle Aladar, a Hungarian Jew who was drafted to fight the Russians in 1916 and spent months in trenches, shooting and getting shot at, and waiting.

title: In Gaza, Even Poetry and Toilets Aren’t Safe From Thieves
description: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

title: Four Great Photography Books Where Words Add Power to Pictures
description: For a documentary photographer who seeks to change the world, images go only so far. Dorothea Lange, a pioneer in the field, put it simply: All photographs, she said, “can be fortified by words.”

title: Lavish Pre-Wedding Parties That Rival the Main Event
description: When Anant Ambani, the youngest son of India’s richest man, married Radhika Merchant in Mumbai this summer, the occasion seemed almost anticlimactic compared with the months of celebrations leading up to their lavish nuptials.

title: A Former Monk Who Won Powerball Is Giving Millions to Theaters
description: When Roy Cockrum, a one-time struggling actor and a former monk, won a $259 million Powerball jackpot in 2014, he decided to splurge on something a bit out of the ordinary: supporting nonprofit theater.

title: Two New Musicals Poke at the Seamy Underbelly of the American Dream
description: “It may surprise you,” Jackie Siegel says, “but we are not old money.”

title: In Palermo, a Catholic Saint Joins the Hindu Pantheon
description: After they spread pink petals on golden statues of Ganesh and Shiva, and recited prayers to blue-skinned and eight-armed gods, the Hindu faithful left their temple and headed to a party for another one of their divinities — the Catholic St. Rosalia.

title: 3 Edge-of-Your-Seat New Thrillers
description: This month’s books deal with disturbances — in people’s minds, in their families and in the heavens. In Sarah Easter Collins’s THINGS DON’T BREAK ON THEIR OWN (Crown, 259 pp., $28) Willa Martenwood has been haunted by the disappearance of her 13-year-old sister, Laika, for more than two decades. One of the manifestations of Willa’s restless obsession is that she sees Laika everywhere, even at the dinner party that begins the story.

title: Harold Makes the World With His Purple Crayon. Who Made Harold?
description: “How does Harold draw himself?” my friend Noam wondered. Noam is 4, so he has a taste for the kind of bracing philosophical speculation that “Harold and the Purple Crayon” — the classic children’s book about a young boy and his magical marker — invites, along with wonder, mischief and delight.

title: He Broke Into a Bank (With Permission). Then He Rented It for $1 a Month.
description: Rarely, in New York City, do you hear stories about tenants getting along with their landlords. But Victor Jeffreys II — a 41-year-old artist who has been living in the same apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, for nearly 20 years — got lucky.

title: Why Are Your Property Taxes Higher Than Your Neighbor’s?
description: Q.: I live in a two-bedroom penthouse in a 174-unit condo building in Midtown, with approximately 1,800 square feet of interior space and 900 square feet of outdoor space. I bought it eight years ago for $2 million. My annual property tax is $60,000. I have seen real estate listings in the city with much lower taxes, such as a four-bedroom house in the Bronx with taxes of $696 a month, and a one-bedroom in Turtle Bay listed for $1.6 million with taxes of $894 a month. Why is my property tax bill so high, and can I appeal it? Or are there ways to lower it?

title: Not Even the Inside of Your Fridge Is Safe From Decorating
description: There’s organizing a fridge, and then there’s fridgescaping: the art of decorating a fridge’s interior.

title: Fires Have Burned 4.5 Million Acres This Year, Blanketing Much of North America in Smoke
description: Devastating wildfires are breaking out across North America on a daily basis, with smoke and ash spreading over large swaths of the continent from Reno to Toronto and New York. Fast-moving blazes have destroyed homes and charred through thousands of acres of farms and forests. Some have become deadly.

title: San Francisco Takes Harder Line Against Homeless Camps, Defying Its Reputation
description: The homeless men who huddled in tents on a wide sidewalk near Golden Gate Park in San Francisco knew that city crews were coming to clear them out. But they did not budge.

title: Should Harris Talk Much About Her Racial Identity? Many Voters Say No.
description: “Obviously, we have eyes.”

title: ‘House of the Dragon’: All the Dragons and Their Riders So Far
description: “House of the Dragon” has finally lived up to its name; it’s all about the dragons ahead of the Season 2 finale, airing Sunday on HBO.

title: Whirlwind Harris Veepstakes Reaches Its Most Eager Phase Yet
description: Just in case anyone had forgotten, Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois released a nearly four-minute video this week promoting his accomplishments in office.

title: ‘I’m Definitely Re-engaged:’ Harris Fuels Energy Among Georgia’s South Asian Voters
description: Kamala Harris is poised to become the first Democratic presidential nominee of South Asian heritage. Her candidacy has reignited debate and engagement among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.

title: Vince Vaughn Turned This Interview Into Self-Help
description: The Vince Vaughn who lives in my head is one of my favorite comedic actors. He’s the swaggering, charmingly sarcastic and cheerily ingratiating star of that great run of hit comedies from the early 2000s: “Old School,” “Dodgeball,” “Wedding Crashers,” “The Break-Up.” (His cameo in “Anchorman” and recurring role as Freddy Funkhouser on “Curb Your Enthusiasm” are also prime comedic Vaughniana.) And putting my own preferences aside, I’d argue that there’s a whole microgeneration of dudes who tried to swipe the neo-Rat Pack vibes that Vaughn was able to deploy so winningly in “Swingers.”

title: The Connections Companion No. 420, August 4, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,142, Sunday, August 4, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Canadian Doctors Warn Against Private Medicine as a Cure for the System’s Ills
description: With perhaps 6.5 million Canadians finding themselves without a personal doctor and with seemingly endless waiting times becoming almost a norm for some medical procedures, private medicine is increasingly being pitched as a solution for those and other problems in Canada’s public health system.

title: Terrorist Attack on Crowded Beachfront in Somalia Kills at Least 32
description: A suicide bomber detonated explosives outside a hotel in a popular beachfront area in Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, before gunmen stormed the building, setting off a four-hour siege that left at least 32 people dead and more than 60 others wounded, the police said on Saturday.

title: The Best Conversations
description: After my recent flight from Maine to New York was canceled, I found myself with the bounty of six hours alone in a rental car. I considered the headway I could make in the audiobook of “Demon Copperhead,” but quickly abandoned that option for several episodes of the podcast “Conan O’Brien Needs a Friend.” I wanted company. If I couldn’t chat away the hours with a passenger in the seat beside me, I wanted to listen to other people hitting it off.

title: Kamala Harris on Center Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Silicon Valley Should Get Behind Kamala Harris
description: There is a major opportunity for Vice President Kamala Harris and the Democrats in the House and Senate to set our country on a different course.

title: Can the Harris Sugar High Last? Yes.
description: With Democratic enthusiasm for Kamala Harris at a fever pitch, the New York Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg spent a day in Atlanta at one of her rallies speaking with voters. In this audio essay, Goldberg argues that the energy among voters she met there is real, and more importantly, will last.

title: Dogs Are the Best! But They Highlight Our Hypocrisy.
description: Over the past couple of decades, dogs have evolved into humans.

title: ‘An End to the Trump Story’: Three Columnists Size Up Harris and Her V.P. Options
description: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Jamelle Bouie, Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg to discuss Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate options — whom she will pick, whom she should pick, the Electoral College landscape for her and for Donald Trump, and what surprises and worries them about Harris, the Democrats, Trump and JD Vance. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: My Erotic Awakening in the Pages of ‘Sweet Valley High’
description: When news broke that Francine Pascal, creator of the “Sweet Valley High” universe, died last weekend at the age of 92, appreciations began rolling across the internet like a certain red Spider through a high school parking lot. “Wildly popular,” “staple of my girlhood,” “G.O.A.T. of publishing,” readers proclaimed. Nostalgic and bereaved, I drove to the library to check out a few, only to discover they had been removed from the catalog.

title: Why Josh Shapiro Would Make Such a Difference for Kamala Harris
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has one overriding weakness as a candidate for president — she is perceived as being to the left of Joe Biden. Ms. Harris has criticized U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, supported single-payer health care and even praised the “defund the police” movement. More recently, opponents have blamed her for what they see as a too-porous southern border.

title: Kamala Harris’s Life in Canada Was Marked by a Yearning for Home
description: While campaigning this past week, Senator JD Vance of Ohio called Vice President Kamala Harris a “phony” who “grew up in Canada,” as former President Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, continued raising false and incendiary questions about the presumed Democratic nominee’s racial identity.

title: Roaring Back After Crackdown, Bangladesh Protesters Demand Leader’s Ouster
description: Fresh protests roiled Bangladesh on Saturday, just weeks after a deadly government crackdown, as demonstrators returned to the streets in what appeared to be the biggest numbers yet and escalated their demands to include the prime minister’s resignation.

title: I Thought I Disliked These Authors. I Was Happy to Be Wrong.
description: Dear readers,

title: Saying the Quiet Part Out Loud
description: Wall Street Democrats have spent the last eight years complaining about their relationship with Washington. They found former President Donald Trump’s presidency unpredictable, and then became estranged from the Democratic Party as President Biden hired the most aggressive antitrust regulators in recent memory. But now that Vice President Kamala Harris is the party’s presumptive presidential nominee, they see a chance to regain influence.

title: Here’s the latest on the presidential race.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, rallied in Atlanta on Saturday night, campaigning in a battleground state where Vice President Kamala Harris rallied earlier this week.

title: Jackie Fox Saw the Dark Side of Rock. Now She’s Playing Her Own Way.
description: Jackie Fox grew up with a guitar in her hand. In 1975, when she was 15 years old, she was pulled off the dance floor at a Hollywood nightclub and recruited to join an all-girl teen rock band. The Runaways became a sensation and tossed Fox and her young bandmates into a turbulent industry that was also violent and sexist. In 1977, Fox quit the band. She never played music professionally again.

title: Israel conducts airstrikes on West Bank, killing 3 members of Hamas military wing.
description: Israel hit a town in the occupied West Bank with two airstrikes on Saturday in the latest use of a once-rare tactic in the densely populated area. Hamas said that three members of its military wing and six other fighters were killed in the strikes around the town of Tulkarm.

title: Cristeta Comerford, White House Chef to 5 Presidents, Retires
description: Growing up in the Philippines, Cristeta Comerford helped her mother, a seamstress, cook for a household of more than a dozen. They were simple meals: rice, a vegetable and fish or chicken, sometimes with extra potatoes to stretch the meal.

title: Who Are the Far-Right Groups Behind the U.K. Riots?
description: Violent unrest has erupted in several towns and cities in Britain in recent days, and further disorder broke out on Saturday as far-right agitators gathered in demonstrations around the country.

title: How JD Vance Thinks About Power
description: In September 2021, JD Vance offered two predictions about former President Donald J. Trump and one piece of advice.

title: Man Who Killed 4 After Dispute Over Stimulus Check Gets 145 Years in Prison
description: An Indianapolis man who killed four people, including a child, after a dispute with his girlfriend over a coronavirus stimulus check was sentenced on Friday to 145 years in prison.

title: When Elder Care Is All in the Stepfamily
description: The encounter happened years ago, but Beverly K. Brandt remembers it vividly.

title: A Times Russia Reporter Reflects on Evan Gershkovich’s Release
description: On Thursday, multiple planes touched down in Ankara, Turkey, releasing 24 people in a seven-nation prisoner exchange that finally resolved a human drama and diplomatic standoff.

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Online Dating After 50 Can Be Miserable. But It’s Also Liberating.’

She didn’t consider dating. She had no time, no emotional energy. But then a year passed. One daughter was off at college, the other increasingly independent. After several more months went by, she started to feel a sliver of curiosity about what kind of men were out there and how it would feel to date again. The last time she dated was 25 years ago, and even then, she fell into relationships mostly with guys from high school, college, parties, work. Now every man she knew was either married, too young, too old or otherwise not a good fit.

title: The Willful Amnesia Behind Trump’s Attacks on Harris’s Identity
description: When I was a child, my dad sat my older sister and me down in our living room and explained to us the rules of race in America. A Black man born into a Mississippi where Black boys could be lynched for merely standing too close to a white woman, he met my white mom in 1972. That was just a few years after the Supreme Court in Loving v. Virginia finally struck down 300 years’ worth of laws prohibiting people who descended from slavery from marrying people whose ancestors had enslaved them. In other words, Dad held no illusions about how race worked in our society and felt it was his duty as a parent to prepare us. Our mother might be white, he told us, but in this country, that fact was irrelevant to how we would be seen and treated. She might be white, but we were Black.
