description: The production company behind Katy Perry’s music video for her single “Lifetimes” is under investigation in Spain for filming in a protected area without clearance, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: Ilhan Omar, a Vocal Critic of Israel and ‘Squad’ Member, Wins Her Primary
description: Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, the progressive lightning rod whose unabated criticism of Israel has deepened the fissures in the Democratic Party over the war in Gaza, won her primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

title: How ‘Deepfake Elon Musk’ Became the Internet’s Biggest Scammer
description: An A.I.-powered version of Mr. Musk has appeared in thousands of inauthentic ads, contributing to billions in fraud.

title: To Save the Panama Canal From Drought, a Disruptive Fix
description: Ricaurte Vásquez Morales is a man obsessed with water. An app on his phone displays the fluctuating level of Lake Gatún, the artificial reservoir that is the centerpiece of the Panama Canal system. He checks it constantly, the way a gambling addict monitors football scores. He keeps a vigilant eye on the weather.

title: He Fled to the U.K. for Safety. Then an Anti-Immigrant Mob Attacked.
description: The mob was growing, encircling the hotel near the northern English town of Rotherham where asylum seekers were living.

title: Our Reporter on the Reshaping of the Panama Canal
description: After a drought that hampered shipping, the Panama Canal’s overseers are eager to expand its water storage. Climate change leaves them no choice.

title: Wednesday Briefing
description: On Aug. 6, Ukraine launched an audacious — and highly secretive — military offensive, with the aim of upending a war it has for months appeared to be losing. The operation surprised even Kyiv’s closest allies, including the U.S., and has pushed the limits of how Western military equipment would be permitted to be used inside Russian territory.

title: Thailand’s Royal Spell Has Been Broken
description: On the surface, Thailand appears to be stuck in a never-ending cycle.

title: Quotation of the Day: Automated Restaurants Face Human Issues
description: “The crux is, if you feel the robot loves you, you allow the robot to cook with love.”

title: Corrections: Aug. 14, 2024
description: An article on Tuesday about real estate investment trusts misstated part of a plan announced in June by the investment firm KKR to support the net asset value of shares in its private REIT. If the net asset value per share is below $27 by June 2027, KKR said it would cancel its own shares in order to increase the value for shareholders; it did not say it would sell its shares.

title: Late Night Recaps Musk’s and Trump’s Two-Hour Chat on X
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: encyclopedic
description: The word encyclopedic has appeared in 72 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 12 in “No Cars, No Crowds: 100 Years of Solitude in the New Mexico Wilderness” by Elaine Glusac:

title: China’s Extreme Fan Culture Makes Olympic Gold a Mixed Blessing
description: A gold medalist diver’s mother said she was afraid for her daughter to come home after their hometown was swarmed with her supporters. A champion swimmer whose hotel was staked out by admirers disbanded his official fan group and told an interviewer he would rather have performed worse if it meant he would be left alone.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: A Nurses’ Union Flexed Its Power. One Hospital Is Pushing Back.
description: Some nurses who worked during Covid’s deadly first wave in March 2020 describe it as a terrifying but also galvanizing experience. Together they confronted mass death and an unknown pathogen, sometimes donning garbage bags when the protective gear ran out.

title: Why Did a Plane Crash in Brazil? A Reporter Looks for Answers.
description: On Friday, a passenger plane headed for São Paulo, Brazil, fell 17,000 feet from the sky.

title: New Zealand Charity Accidentally Gives Away Meth Disguised as Candy
description: The police in New Zealand were trying on Wednesday to recover chunks of methamphetamine that a local charity accidentally gave out because they were disguised as candy.

title: How ‘The Challenge’ Made Reality TV a Real Career
description: When Johnny Devenanzio swiveled in his chair and playfully called for his mother to bring some meatloaf, he knew exactly what he was doing. In his impression of Will Ferrell’s man-child from “Wedding Crashers,” he was really evoking Johnny Bananas, the Peter Pan-like alter ego he has played for much of his adult life on the grandfather of all reality-competition shows: MTV’s “The Challenge.”

title: New York’s Promising Experiment in Making the Subways Safer
description: Ameed Ademolu, a close-cropped and bespectacled nurse, descends the street-level stairs to the subway, clad in an orange and yellow vest and carrying a clipboard, paper and pencil. He halts, reaches into a pocket to unfold a KN95 mask and fits it over his mouth and nose. “The mask is for me,” he says, because “I’ve had people spit in my face.”

title: Family Is a Lot of Trouble in August’s Graphic Novels
description: The warp and weft of a single life is impossible to describe because there’s no such thing as a single life. Perhaps that’s why family stories are such a satisfying microcosm — they ask us not to consider one person’s vast depths, but to think about how a collection of people form and change one another over their shared lives.

title: 5 Health Trends We Debunked This Year
description: About a decade ago, a massage therapist in Santa Cruz, Calif., gave me a lecture on the healing properties of coconut oil.

title: A New Line of Clothes Fit for Magical Rituals, or Just Errands
description: While studying fashion at New York’s Parsons School of Design and later London’s Central Saint Martins — from which she graduated in 2019 — the designer Colleen Allen, 28, was drawn to men’s wear. It aligned with her tomboyish personal style (she grew up in Chicago with two older brothers, as well as a younger sister) and, having been taught how to sew as a child by her quilter grandmother, Nana Dot, she was more interested in tailoring than draping. She was also excited by the ways that masculine dress codes were being re-examined at the time, thanks to designers and celebrities such as Jonathan Anderson and Young Thug. “I wanted to be a part of that,” she says, “where it could really feel like you were doing something new.”

title: What Does It Take to Learn to Garden? A Willingness to Do It Yourself.
description: If there were a manual on making your first garden, Chapter 1 would presumably recommend that beginners identify a piece of level ground where they can carve out a not-too-big bed or build a raised one.

title: Do Politicians Realize How Difficult and Rare Immigrating to the U.S. Legally Actually Is?
description: During the Republican National Convention, speakers repeatedly tried to draw a contrast between asylum seekers who’ve crossed the southern border in recent years and immigrants who’ve entered the country through other channels. As Vivek Ramaswamy put it, legal immigrants like his parents “deserve the opportunity to secure a better life for your children in America.” Others deserve deportation, “because you broke the law.”

title: An Indigenous Author Offers Ancestral Answers to Today’s Environmental Crises
description: When Ailton Krenak walked, barefoot, onto the stage of a packed auditorium during a book festival in Rio de Janeiro, the crowd hushed. He lifted the microphone, sending earsplitting feedback across the room.

title: They All Got Mysterious Brain Diseases. They’re Fighting to Learn Why.
description: In late 2018, after an otherwise-normal Christmas holiday, Laurie Beatty started acting strange. An 81-year-old retired contractor, he grew unnaturally quiet and began poring over old accounting logs from a construction business he sold decades earlier, convinced that he had been bilked in the deal.

title: As Democrats Gather in Chicago, These Audiobooks Offer Context
description: Never one to tread lightly, Norman Mailer once declared Chicago “the great American city.” It did not strive, he argued, to New York’s global status, yet it managed to outshine “the dull diamonds in the smog of Eastern Megalopolis,” as Mailer derided Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington, D.C.

title: The Wonder Seasoning Your Salad Is Missing
description: When I was a kid, I was sure there was a “someone” who was an “everyone.” If a certain group of us was sitting around, someone might walk in and say, “Hey, where’s everyone?” If there was another group of the same size, that person might walk in and say, “Hey, everyone.” Who’s “everyone”? Who’s the one person whose presence means that nothing, or no one, is missing?

title: A California Bill to Regulate A.I. Causes Alarm in Silicon Valley
description: A California bill that could impose restrictions on artificial intelligence has tech companies, investors and activists scrambling to explain what the first-of-its-kind legislation could mean for their industry in the state.

title: Cailee Spaeny Is Still Learning How to Be a Star
description: The actress Cailee Spaeny, the seventh of nine children born to committed Southern Baptists, left school in Missouri at 13. She had found work at a theme park, Silver Dollar City, in the Ozark Mountains, which allowed her to strike out on her own.

title: Catholic Converts Like JD Vance Are Reshaping Republican Politics
description: Despite institutional decline and internal conflict, Catholicism retains a surprising resonance in American life — especially in certain elite circles. It has emerged as the largest and perhaps the most vibrant religious group at many top universities. It claims six of the nine Supreme Court justices as adherents. It continues to win high-profile converts, and its social teaching exerts an influence (often unacknowledged) on public debates, inspiring political thinkers who seek to challenge both the cultural left and the laissez-faire right.

title: Robert Wilson’s Chance Encounters
description: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Robert Wilson explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.

title: Kamala Harris Had a Great Health Care Idea in 2019. She Should Embrace It.
description: From the moment Kamala Harris became the presumptive Democratic nominee, Republicans have sought to paint her as a far-left California liberal. After all, they argue, she supported getting rid of private health insurance in her 2019 presidential campaign.

title: Walz Faces New Scrutiny Over 2020 Riots: Was He Too Slow to Send Troops?
description: The protests had turned into riots.

title: How the World’s Oldest Humpback Whale Has Survived Is a Mystery
description: A humpback whale’s tail is as unique as a fingerprint. The lobes, or flukes, at the end of the tail have scalloped edges that vary from whale to whale; the undersides feature distinct black-and-white patterns that mark a whale for life.

title: Gwen Walz, the Coolheaded, Ultracompetent Political Spouse
description: In 2006, during his first campaign for Congress, Tim Walz was scheduled to speak at a fund-raising dinner in his hometown, Mankato, Minn. At the time, he was a political unknown in a tightly contested race against a six-term incumbent. The dinner was a chance to stump in front of his local district of the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party and to bolster his campaign coffers.

title: I’m a Liberal. We Need to Face an Awkward Truth.
description: Nicholas Kristof is an Oregonian and, he is quick to point out, a liberal. But in this audio essay, Kristof takes liberals to task for their governing of cities on the West Coast. It’s an election year, and so he asks the question he believes many Americans are thinking: “Why put liberals in charge nationally when the places around the country where liberals have the greatest control are plagued by homelessness, crime and dysfunction?”

title: $280,000 Homes in Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Maryland
description: This house is in the Willard-Hay neighborhood, a few blocks from Willard Park. It is within walking distance of several amenities: the sports fields and seasonal water park at North Commons Park; Theodore Wirth Regional Park, an expanse of more than 700 acres with a lake, walking trails and a clubhouse; and the Capri, a performing arts center built in 1927. Public elementary and high schools are within a five-minute drive.

title: A Pigeon Named Dinosaur Will Sit on the High Line
description: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about a giant featherless bird that will land on the High Line in Manhattan before long. We’ll also get details on a pretrial hearing in the criminal fraud case against former Representative George Santos.

title: Inflation Cools to 2.9%, Shoring Up Case for a Fed Rate Cut
description: The Consumer Price Index cooled in July compared with a year earlier, providing further evidence that inflation is moderating and leaving the Federal Reserve firmly on track to cut interest rates at its meeting next month.

title: Inflation Data Is the Next Hurdle for Investors Weary From Volatility
description: Wall Street is on edge heading into the July consumer price report after sharp stock swings this month reignited fears over the fate of the economy.

title: What People Wear in One of the Happiest Places on Earth
description: Not every fashion week can be characterized as friendly, approachable and relaxed. But those are three ways to describe Copenhagen Fashion Week, a twice-a-year event in the capital city of Denmark, a country that has often been ranked among the happiest in the world.

title: As Famine Deepens in Sudan, U.S. Leads New Push for Cease-Fire
description: The United States opened new peace talks on Wednesday that aim to stop Sudan’s catastrophic civil war, driven by a growing sense of urgency that the country’s deepening famine, which threatens millions of lives, could become the world’s worst in decades.

title: Tracking the Swing States for Harris and Trump
description: The presidential race will most likely come down to voters in eight states that remain competitive.

title: Late-Summer Travel Plans? You Might Want to Put On a Mask.
description: It is the height of the summer travel season: Airplanes and cruises are packed, hotels are booked, and travelers are crowding theme parks and attractions. Yet throughout the United States, Covid-19 is currently circulating at very high levels.

title: Sex and Murder on Trial: ‘Presumed Innocent’
description: When Scott Turow’s best-selling novel “Presumed Innocent” was first published in 1987, it was quickly adapted for the big screen. The film — released in 1990 — was a Hollywood blockbuster, featuring one of the biggest movie stars of the time, Harrison Ford. Over 30 years later, Apple TV+ has rebooted it, this time as an eight-part series starring Jake Gyllenhaal as Rusty Sabich, a prosecutor turned defendant. Our critic Wesley Morris and Parul Sehgal, a staff writer at The New Yorker, discuss the book, the film and the TV series, and ask the question: Why do we need this remake now? (Beware: This episode contains spoilers).

title: How Extreme Heat Is Threatening Education Progress Worldwide
description: The continued burning of fossil fuels is closing schools around the world for days, sometimes weeks at a time, and threatening to undermine one of the greatest global gains of recent decades: children’s education.

title: Trial in Texas School Shooting Asks: Could the Gunman’s Parents Have Stopped It?
description: As the nation has struggled to respond to mass shootings, often carried out by teenagers still living at home, focus has turned to the parents of the gunmen and whether they bear responsibility for the horrific acts of their children.

title: Thai Court Ejects Prime Minister, as Old Guard Reasserts Power
description: Thailand’s Constitutional Court ousted Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin from office on Wednesday, throwing the country into fresh political turmoil just days after the court dissolved the country’s main opposition party.

title: Endless Honking of Waymo’s Driverless Taxis Wakes a Neighborhood
description: It was a little over two weeks ago that Sophia Tung began waking up before dawn to the sound of cars honking.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,153
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 431
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Abortion Access on the Ballot, and Hamas Won’t Attend Peace Talks
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: How One Tech Monopoly Paved the Way for Another
description: In a landmark antitrust ruling against Google last week, another case was at the heart of the story — one from the 1990s.

title: Ukraine’s Surprise Attack Forces Russia to Divert Forces in Response
description: Since its surprise incursion into Russia more than a week ago, Ukraine has steadily gained ground, saying it advanced even deeper into Russian territory on Wednesday. It says it has captured hundreds of soldiers, as Russia has evacuated more than 130,000 people from nearby communities and declared a new state of emergency in one region.

title: The Global Race to Control A.I.
description: As artificial intelligence advances, many nations are worried about being left behind.

title: Makers of Snickers and Pringles to Merge in $36 Billion Food Deal
description: Mars, the company behind M&M’s and Snickers, has agreed to acquire Kellanova, the snack food business spun off by Kellogg’s last year, in a multibillion-dollar deal that will create a new global food giant.

title: Harris Is Set to Lay Out an Economic Message Light on Detail
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s sudden ascent to the top of the Democratic ticket has generated a host of questions about her economic agenda, including how much she will stick to the details of President Biden’s positions, tweak them, or chart entirely new ones.

title: Google’s Stock Falls as the Government Weighs Breaking Up the Company
description: Shares in Alphabet, Google’s parent company, were down more than 2.5 percent in early trading on Wednesday morning on news that the Justice Department is considering breaking up the technology giant for maintaining an illegal search monopoly.

title: Judge Denies Trump’s Recusal Bid, Rebuking Him for Claiming Harris Ties
description: The judge who oversaw Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial declined for a third time to step aside from the case, rebuking the former president’s lawyers for claiming that the judge had a distant yet problematic connection to Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: Can I Tell My Sister That Her Estranged Son Is a New Father?
description: My nephew has been estranged from his parents for three years after they had some difficult conversations. I don’t know all the details, and I have tried to remain neutral. When my nephew married, his parents were not at the wedding. Then he and his wife moved several hours away. They now have an infant son, and as far as I know, my sister and her husband are unaware of their grandchild’s existence. My nephew and I keep in touch. I suggested he tell his parents about the baby, but I don’t know if he did. I feel disloyal to my sister, withholding this news. In her position, I would want to know about the baby. But I don’t have my nephew’s permission to tell her, and he may object. Complicating matters: I have issues with my sister, and we are barely speaking. What should I do?

title: His Trilogy Explored the Nazi Era. Now He Looks at the People Behind It.
description: “Who Goes Nazi?” is an old essay by Dorothy Thompson that has been making the rounds over the last several years. Writing for Harper’s Magazine in 1941, Thompson suggested playing a “macabre parlor game” to figure out who would sign on to fascism “in a showdown.” (This was before the Wannsee Conference of January 1942, where Hitler’s underlings planned the “final solution.”) Decades later, Thompson’s proposal resonated with Americans who were seeking any glimmer of insight into how far-right extremism — once the marginal purview of dedicated fanatics — had gathered startling levels of popular support.

title: What Teachers Told Me About A.I. in School
description: Leila Wheless, a North Carolina teacher who has been an educator since 1991, tried to keep “an open heart” about using artificial intelligence in her middle school English and language arts classroom. She reviewed the guidance of her state’s generative A.I. “recommendations and considerations” for public schools. But the results of her students’ A.I. use were dispiriting.

title: Deaths at the Grand Canyon Are on the Rise. Here’s How to Stay Safe.
description: The Grand Canyon, one of the most celebrated natural wonders in the United States, known for its deep valleys and rust-colored views, has been the site of multiple deaths this summer, raising concerns about hiker safety at the park.

title: Germany Issues Arrest Warrant for Ukrainian Over Nord Stream Explosion
description: A European arrest warrant was issued for a Ukrainian man suspected of involvement in blowing up the Nord Stream pipeline nearly two years ago, Polish prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: Meet a Family That’s Betting the Farm on a Wild Idea. Literally.
description: For years Rand Faaborg, a father of five in rural Iowa, wanted to get out of hog farming. He just didn’t know how.

title: Teamsters’ Black Caucus Endorses Harris While Parent Union Stays Silent
description: The National Black Caucus of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters union endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris for the presidency on Tuesday, setting it apart from its parent union, which has declined to make an endorsement and whose president spoke at the Republican National Convention.

title: 5 Things This Bulgari Designer Wishes She’d Made
description: Why Mary Katrantzou admires Audubon's illustrations, an Issey Miyake bodice and the rainbow flag.

title: This Enormous Artwork Turns a Palace Into a Pawnshop
description: Ascending the grand marble staircase in the center of the Venetian palazzo, you encounter a selection of fake Gucci, Hermes and other luxury handbags laid out on a blanket. A street hawker seems to have been disturbed, leaving their knockoff wares behind.

title: How Christian Conservatives Are Planning for the Next Battle, on I.V.F.
description: The pivot seems clear. The Republican Party of the post-Roe era is sidelining anti-abortion activists. Project 2025, the conservative blueprint with innovative abortion bans, has been disavowed by Donald Trump. And the new G.O.P. platform even promises to advance access to in vitro fertilization.

title: Yes, You Can Run a Marathon
description: When you cross the finish line of your first marathon, the high can make it easy to forget about everything you’ve put your mind and body through to get there. There’s no question that covering 26.2 miles is an impressive feat of endurance and athleticism, but it can be an attainable goal for most runners with the right preparation.

title: Illuminating a Trailblazing Artist Who Died Too Young
description: An exultant sense of discovery is the propelling through line of “Paula Modersohn-Becker: Ich Bin Ich / I Am Me,” a glorious exhibition at the Neue Galerie that is, surprisingly, the German artist’s first retrospective in an American museum. (It will travel to the Art Institute of Chicago in October.)

title: A Chicken Dinner That Tastes Like Your Favorite Italian Dressing
description: Good morning! Eric here, filling in for Melissa.

title: The Tony Winner Behind ‘Appropriate’ Is Back. This Time, With ‘Purpose.’
description: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins won a Tony Award in June for the Broadway production of “Appropriate,” his blistering play about a white Southern family grappling with some serious baggage.

title: Off the Grid, Extremely Online
description: Nate Petroski’s address doesn’t help visitors find his house. Locating it, instead, requires specific GPS coordinates to a spot deep in West Virginia’s Appalachian Mountains, and precise instructions on how to get there. Many of the surrounding roads are impassable without an ATV to traverse several creeks and muddy inclines.

title: For Stonehenge’s Altar Stone, an Improbably Long Ancient Journey
description: Near the center of the roughly 5,000-year-old circular monument known as Stonehenge is a six-ton, rectangular chunk of red sandstone. In Arthurian legend, the so-called Altar Stone was part of the ring of giant rocks that the wizard Merlin magically transported from Mount Killaurus, in Ireland, to Salisbury Plain, a chalk plateau in southern England — a journey chronicled around 1136 by a Welsh cleric, Geoffrey of Monmouth, in his “Historia Regum Britanniae.”

title: Cooling Price Growth Has Democrats Tasting Victory Over Inflation
description: After more than two years of being politically battered over soaring prices, Wednesday’s inflation report left many Democrats feeling victorious.

title: Hurricane Ernesto Knocks Out Power to Hundreds of Thousands in Puerto Rico
description: Hurricane Ernesto left hundreds of thousands of Puerto Ricans without power on Wednesday after its wind and rain pelted the island’s frail electrical system.

title: My Aunt’s Son Shouldn’t Be a Dad. Must I Congratulate Her on the New Grandkid?
description: I have an aunt with whom I’ve always had a warm relationship. She has an adult son whom I am not close to and who seems to have many struggles. Over the past few years, this son has been in relationships that have resulted in multiple pregnancies. My aunt is always excited about these pregnancies and seems to expect congratulations — even though, by her own admission, she does not trust her son to be alone with his own child. Now that my cousin is expecting another baby, I feel bad not to have reached out with congratulations or even support. But I also feel it would be disingenuous to do so. It doesn’t seem like my place to express my concern. What seems appropriate? — Name Withheld

title: Harris Is Leading or Tied With Trump in Most Swing States, New Cook Polls Find
description: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are locked into a tight race in key swing states, according to new polling from the Cook Political Report and the bipartisan team of BSG and GS Strategy Group published Wednesday.

title: U.C.L.A. Can’t Let Protesters Block Jewish Students From Campus, Judge Says
description: A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily barred the University of California, Los Angeles, from allowing protesters to block Jewish students from having access to the campus and facilities such as libraries, classrooms and gathering places.

title: Does Harris Actually Need to Move Democrats Right?
description: The ascension of Kamala Harris to the top of the Democratic ticket has prompted, among many other things, a reckoning with the meaning and legacy of the last decade of American liberalism.

title: Trump Gambles on Outside Groups to Finance Voter Outreach Efforts
description: The Republican campaign for president is quietly being remade by new federal guidelines that empower big-money groups and threaten to undermine party control well beyond the 2024 election.

title: Readers’ Pleas to The Times: Don’t End the New York Endorsements
description: To the Editor:

title: Harris Shouldn’t Forget That Democracy Is Still on the Ballot
description: Kamala Harris is running an artful campaign so far, thanks in part to her upbeat, hopeful message. She has shrewdly positioned herself as the change candidate — no small feat for a sitting vice president — and has tagged Donald Trump as representing the weird past we should leave behind.

title: Whimsical Parade of Banksy Animals Sends Fans on a Giddy Hunt
description: The first Banksy piece to show up was a mountain goat, spotted by passers-by on a wall near the River Thames. The second work, a pair of elephants, appeared overnight on a house in southwest London. Then came some playful monkeys, a howling wolf, two hungry pelicans and a cat.

title: ‘Life and Trust’ Review: Choose Your Own Faustian Adventure
description: In one room in Conwell Tower, a stately skyscraper in the Financial District, a police officer strips off his shirt and flogs himself — passionately, even sensually — before coolly donning his uniform again. At the end of a long hall, a woman performs a Houdini-esque escape from a straitjacket. Elsewhere, in a dark underground boxing ring, two men trade punches in a cinematic fight scene where lights flash and dim with each maneuver, the bodies sometimes moving in slow motion like scenes from a “Rocky” film.

title: Ukraine’s Surprise Attack on Russia
description: Amid the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited a place where Ukrainian forces stormed in. Andrew E. Kramer, the Kyiv bureau chief for The New York Times, describes what he saw.

title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘BoJack Horseman’ and More
description: I’m a food columnist for The New York Times Magazine. Here are five things I’ve recently relished.

title: Contaminants Found at German Military Base, and Sabotage Is Suspected
description: Two military bases in Germany were put under heightened security on Wednesday after contaminants were found in the water supply of barracks at one site — the result of possible sabotage, the military said — and an intruder attempted to forcibly enter a NATO base in the country.

title: Ask TikTok’s ‘Cucumber Boy’ How to Prepare a Cucumber
description: Logan Moffitt has never been more hydrated.

title: W.H.O. Declares Global Emergency Over New Mpox Outbreak
description: The rapid spread of mpox, formerly called monkeypox, in African countries constitutes a global health emergency, the World Health Organization declared on Wednesday.

title: Bronx Museum’s Executive Director Leaves During $33 Million Expansion
description: The head of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, which recently began a $33 million expansion and renovation project, is leaving his position to lead the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Hurricane Ernesto Causes Power Outages in Puerto Rico
description: Hundreds of thousands on the island lost power as the Category 1 storm strained the island’s frail electrical system.

title: Peach Cobbler, 2 Ways: Spectacularly Simple and Simply Spectacular
description: Generally filled with bubbling fruit nestled into a buttery, sugary foundation, cobblers are beloved in the canon of homey desserts. The problem is, there’s no consensus about what, exactly, they are.

title: Boeing Faces a Steep Climb in Catching Up to Airbus
description: Four years ago, Airbus scored a major victory: For the first time in its history, more of its passenger planes were flying around the world than those made by its rival, Boeing. Airbus has only tightened its grip on the market since.

title: Coming to ‘iPhone City’: An Electric Car Factory From Foxconn
description: The core of Foxconn’s business is in Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan province in central China, known as “iPhone City.” That’s where a network of suppliers, infrastructure and factories, and sometimes as many as 250,000 Foxconn employees, manufacture most of the world’s iPhones for Apple.

title: California ‘Shaman’ Faces Felony Sex Assault Charges
description: A man in Southern California who the authorities say led a shamanistic community in Riverside County was arraigned last week on charges that he sexually assaulted two female victims, including at least one who was under 14.

title: Wally Amos, Enterprising Creator of Famous Amos Cookies, Dies at 88
description: Wally Amos, an indefatigable entrepreneur who in 1975 took a $25,000 loan from a few friends in Hollywood to start Famous Amos, one of the first brands to push high-quality cookies in its own stores and one of the world’s best-known names in baked goods, died on Tuesday at his home in Honolulu. He was 88.

title: Jay Kanter, Agent for Marlon Brando and Marilyn Monroe, Dies at 97
description: Jay Kanter, whose long career as an agent to the stars — including Marlon Brando, Marilyn Monroe and Grace Kelly — and later as a studio executive made him one of the last of the generation of power brokers who dominated Hollywood in the late 20th century, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 97.

title: When Will They Speak Again? Once Close, Biden and Pelosi Are at Odds.
description: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited San Francisco as a freshly minted senator and single father in the early 1970s, it was a well-known local fund-raiser and stay-at-home mother of five, Nancy Pelosi, who lent him her Jeep to get around town.

title: Summer 2024 News Quiz for Students
description: How closely have you paid attention to current events? See what you remember by taking our special Summer 2024 News Quiz.

title: Black Art Week in San Francisco Bay Area Is in the Works for the Fall
description: When Monetta White was a co-owner of the San Francisco restaurant 1300 on Fillmore a decade ago, she participated in the city’s restaurant week, promoting the local food scene. Now, as the executive director of the Museum of the African Diaspora downtown, she is organizing a celebration of Black visual culture, called “Nexus: SF/Bay Area Black Art Week,” to run Oct. 1 through Oct. 6.

title: A New Venue Beckons Jazz Musicians and Beyond to Upstate New York
description: Fourteen years ago, Taylor Haskins, a veteran jazz trumpeter, and Catherine Ross Haskins, a visual artist, moved from Brooklyn to Westport, N.Y., a picture-book town on Lake Champlain, 275 miles north of Manhattan. It became “the place on Earth that we love,” Taylor said. “But sometimes it could use a little bit of an injection of the outside world.”

title: U.S. Army Soldier Pleads Guilty to Selling Military Documents
description: An Army soldier pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy and bribery charges in connection with a plot in which prosecutors said he sold dozens of U.S. military documents that disclosed details about rocket systems and Chinese military tactics to a foreign national.

title: City Approves $7 Million Settlement for Exonerated Former Death Row Inmate
description: An Oklahoma city has agreed to pay $7.15 million to settle a lawsuit filed by a former death row inmate who spent more than 48 years in prison before being exonerated in December, his lawyers said this week.

title: What to Know About Mpox
description: Mpox was declared a global health emergency on Wednesday for the second time in three years, as the World Health Organization urged action on a virus spreading rapidly through more than a dozen African countries.

title: Unresponsive Brain-Damaged Patients May Have Some Awareness
description: When people suffer severe brain damage — as a result of car crashes, for example, or falls or aneurysms — they may slip into a coma for weeks, their eyes closed, their bodies unresponsive.

title: NASA Says It Needs to Decide Soon How Starliner Astronauts Will Come Home
description: A week ago, NASA officials said they would most likely need to decide by mid-August on how to safely bring home two astronauts who had traveled to the International Space Station on Boeing’s troubled Starliner spacecraft. But on Wednesday, NASA said a decision remained at least a week away.

title: A.L.S. Stole His Voice. A.I. Retrieved It.
description: Four years ago, Casey Harrell sang his last bedtime nursery rhyme to his daughter.

title: In Gaza, Israel’s Military Has Reached the End of the Line, U.S. Officials Say
description: Israel has achieved all that it can militarily in Gaza, according to senior American officials, who say continued bombings are only increasing risks to civilians while the possibility of further weakening Hamas has diminished.

title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Assesses Israel’s War in Gaza
description: Mediators, Israeli negotiators and officials from around the world are expected to meet in Qatar today for a high-stakes push to end the war in Gaza.

title: Google Pixel Documents a Fashion House in Its 20th Year
description: Fashion designer Phillip Lim and photographer Andy Jackson used Google Pixel 9 Pro and its AI-powered editing features in a portrait session dedicated to the women who inspired Lim’s career.

title: Inflation Fell Below 3% for the First Time in Years
description: Annual inflation cooled more than expected last month, to 2.9 percent, according to a Consumer Price Index report released today. It was the first time that the inflation gauge had dropped below 3 percent since 2021.

title: Can a Disney+ Subscription Keep a Widower From Suing Disney in Court?
description: Months after a man sued Walt Disney Parks and Resorts over the death of his wife from a severe allergic reaction at a Disney World restaurant, the company responded with an argument that would keep the case from coming before a jury.

title: Just How Demure Are You?
description: If you opened TikTok this week and felt that suddenly everyone was using the word “demure” out of nowhere, you’re not alone.

title: A Hulk Hogan-Jesse Ventura Grudge Match, in the Political Arena
description: When Jesse “The Body” Ventura faced off against Hulk Hogan in the 1980s, Mr. Ventura played the heel — the caped villain whose staged cheap shots and provocations rallied the audience to the side of the mustachioed hero, glistening triumphantly in his underwear.

title: Cisco Systems to Cut About 7% of Staff in Second Round of Layoffs
description: Cisco Systems, one of the largest makers of computer networking equipment, said on Wednesday that it would cut 7 percent of its work force in its second major round of layoffs this year.

title: Rabbi Shmuel Butman, 81, a Brooklyn Voice of Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Is Dead
description: Rabbi Shmuel Butman, who was the public face of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic sect during the antisemitic riots in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991, and who was literally a keeper of that ultra-Orthodox Jewish movement’s flame by illuminating its menorah — billed as the world’s largest — across from Central Park every Hanukkah for decades, died on July 22 in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: ‘I’m Looking for a Job’: Biden Jokes About Life After the White House
description: With just over 22 weeks left in charge of the country, President Biden is looking for work.

title: Wyoming Reporter Resigns After Using A.I. to Fabricate Quotes
description: A novice reporter for the Cody Enterprise in Wyoming resigned this month after he was caught using generative artificial intelligence to help write his stories, resulting in numerous fabricated quotes, according to editors at the paper and published reports.

title: Another ‘Nasty’ Woman Strikes Fear in Trump
description: Misogyny has been central to Donald Trump’s identity, rise and political movement, but it is now central to his distemper, as Kamala Harris’s remarkable campaign rollout has frustrated and unnerved him.

title: In Economy-Focused Speech, Trump Still Lobs Personal Attacks Against Harris
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s speech on Wednesday in Asheville, N.C., his first event in a battleground state in nearly two weeks, was supposed to offer him a bit of a reset after his Democratic opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, gained significant momentum.

title: Betty A. Prashker, 99, Who Pushed Boundaries in Book Publishing, Dies
description: Betty A. Prashker, a pioneering woman in the book business who published the feminist classics “Sexual Politics” by Kate Millett and “Backlash” by Susan Faludi, but who also brought out racy commercial fiction by Judith Krantz and Jean M. Auel — viewing their frank female sexuality as no less a statement of feminist empowerment — died on July 30 in Alford, Mass. She was 99.

title: It’s Instincts Over Strategy for Trump
description: When Donald Trump held a news conference last week, ostensibly to hit Vice President Kamala Harris for not yet having held one of her own, he said something revealing about how her sudden climb up the Democratic ticket had shaped his own campaign for the presidency — or not.

title: Search Continues After Inmate Escapes Prison Transport Van in North Carolina
description: Law enforcement officers in North Carolina continued their search on Thursday for a convicted murderer who was serving a life sentence and escaped custody on Tuesday morning, according to the state’s Department of Adult Correction.

title: Connecticut Official Loses to Jewish Opponent After Antisemitic Comments
description: A Connecticut state representative lost a primary election Tuesday, just hours after a video surfaced of her saying that her challenger should not represent the district because he is Jewish.

title: Columbia President Resigns After Months of Turmoil on Campus
description: Columbia University’s president, Nemat Shafik, resigned on Wednesday after months of far-reaching fury over her handling of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and questions over her management of a bitterly divided campus.

title: Jewish Man Charged With Attempted Murder in Attacks on Muslim Neighbor
description: A Jewish man in Brooklyn was arrested and charged with attempted murder and hate crimes after repeatedly attacking his Muslim neighbor over several months, ultimately breaking into the neighbor’s apartment and striking him so hard with a mallet that he had internal bleeding, according to a criminal complaint.

title: M.T.A. Is Ordered to Improve Track Safety After Transit Worker Is Killed
description: Federal transportation officials said on Wednesday that the death of a transit worker who was hit by a train in November, as well as a rising number of “near-miss” incidents on train tracks last year, reflected unsafe conditions and practices that were putting transit employees at growing risk.

title: Gena Rowlands, Actress Who Brought Raw Drama to Her Roles, Dies at 94
description: Gena Rowlands, the intense, elegant dramatic actress who, often in collaboration with her husband, John Cassavetes, starred in a series of introspective independent films, has died. She was 94.

title: What to Know About the State of the Cease-Fire Talks
description: Israel’s war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip has lasted more than 10 months, with only one weeklong pause in fighting, in late November. That cease-fire led to the return of more than  100 Israeli hostages captured during the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel in exchange for  Palestinian prisoners and raised hopes among mediators and the international community that another deal would follow.

title: Kennedy Sought a Meeting With Harris to Discuss a Cabinet Post
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent presidential candidate whose standing has dropped in the polls, sought a meeting with Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss endorsing her in exchange for a promise of a cabinet post, according to two people briefed on the outreach who insisted on anonymity to discuss private conversations.

title: Woman Sentenced to Nine Years for Stealing $1.5 Million in Chicken Wings
description: A former food service director for an Illinois school district was sentenced to prison for stealing more than $1 million worth of chicken wings that were billed to the district but never given to students, the authorities said.

title: Where Lines May Be Drawn in the Sand
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: 10 Terrific Gena Rowlands Performances to Stream
description: Gena Rowlands, who died Wednesday at the age of 94, was widely regarded as one of the best actresses of her generation, known for her vulnerable portraits of women in states of crisis. Her most acclaimed performances came through her prolific and intensely creative collaboration with her husband, the director, writer and actor John Cassavetes, who gave her parts like the housewife in turmoil in “A Woman Under the Influence.” Even after his death in 1989, Rowlands would continue to work with family members, starring in the directorial efforts of their son, Nick, and her daughter Zoe. And while she became a star of the 1970s with films that broke new ground in independent cinema, in her later years she was introduced to a younger generation, thanks to Nick Cassavetes’s blockbuster tear-jerker, “The Notebook.” Here is where to watch some of her best work.

title: Bowling, Selfies and the ‘Dougie’: Biden Woos Influencers at the White House
description: As soon as President Biden walked into the Indian Treaty Room across the street from the White House on Wednesday, the smartphones flew up. Dozens of social media influencers and people who work with them stood almost in unison to capture the moment.

title: Harris Will Back Federal Ban on Price Gouging, Campaign Says
description: Vice President Kamala Harris will call for a federal ban on corporate price gouging on groceries in a speech laying out her economic agenda on Friday, campaign officials said late Wednesday, in an effort to blame big companies for persistently high costs of American consumer staples.

title: Quotation of the Day: Fleeing Sudan Conflict, Only to Find in England a Mob Menacing Them
description: “This is not freedom.”

title: The British Have Finally Learned to Love Peanut Butter
description: When the American political commentator and noted peanut butter lover William F. Buckley Jr. arrived at an English boarding school in the late 1930s, care packages from home would include jars of peanut butter, which his British peers, he later wrote, “one after another actually spit out.”

title: To Solve Its Housing Crisis, Britain Turns to an Old Idea: New Towns
description: On a baking hot afternoon in July, Firouz Thompson proudly drove down the freshly paved road that leads into Northstowe, a new town about six miles northwest of Cambridge, England.

title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia Flips the Script on Putin
description: Families fleeing invading Ukrainian troops sought shelter from strangers. Russian parents feared that their children might be sent into battle for the first time.

title: Corrections: Aug. 15, 2024
description: An article on Wednesday about a study highlighting how extreme rainfall was made 10 percent heavier by human-caused climate change misstated the name of a scientific organization. It is the Kentucky Geologic Survey, not the Kentucky Geologic Society.

title: A Chinese Self-Driving Start-Up Is About to Go Public in the U.S.
description: One of China’s leading autonomous driving start-ups is set to go public in New York as soon as this week, with the strained relationship between Beijing and Washington lurking in the background.

title: Thursday Briefing
description: The Israeli military has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, according to senior American officials who say continued bombings are only increasing risks to civilians.

title: There Is Still Time to Stop a Wider War in the Middle East
description: Since the Oct. 7 Hamas terrorist attack on Israel, President Biden has had two goals in the Middle East: to support Israel’s right to defend itself against terrorism and to prevent the Israel-Hamas war from escalating into a regional conflagration that would compel the United States to step in.

title: Word of the Day: boycott
description: The word boycott has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in “Kandinsky Cut Ties With Russia. So Did This Museum” by Nina Siegal:

title: Seth Meyers Calls Trump ‘Desperate’ for Likes
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: U.K. Economy Buoyed by Reports on Growth, Inflation and Jobs
description: The British economy grew relatively strongly in the spring, data on Thursday showed, the latest in a string of positive economic news.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: In South Korea, Documenting a Divide Over Work-Life Balance
description: I spent much of my childhood in the United States and Canada but have lived in South Korea for all of my adult life. I have noticed one stark contrast between the places I grew up in and South Korea: people’s attitude toward work. In North America, it seems to me that people look for jobs that they are interested in or passionate about. In South Korea, people often prioritize jobs that offer prestige and better reputations.

title: He Survived Combat in Iraq. Did a Fellow Soldier Kill Him at Home?
description: On Friday, Aug. 2, U.S. Army Specialist Jacob Ashton left Fort Drum in upstate New York for the five-and-a-half-hour drive to his hometown in Ohio, where he spent the weekend with his girlfriend.

title: Float Planned for N.Y.C. India Day Parade Is Condemned as Anti-Muslim
description: A float slated to appear in New York City’s India Day Parade this weekend is causing an uproar, with community groups calling it a symbol of anti-Muslim hate, parade organizers defending its inclusion and elected officials scrambling to respond.

title: Who’s Up Next in Japan? Here Are 5 Potential Leaders.
description: When Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to step down on Wednesday, he vowed that his departure would clear the way for a new leader who could bring change to Japan’s long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

title: At a Festival Amid Industrial Ruins, Ivo van Hove Takes Charge
description: The calling card of the Ruhrtriennale Festival of the Arts is to present shows in former industrial sites, like power stations or coal plants, among cities in the Ruhr region of northwestern Germany. For the theater-maker Ivo van Hove, who is presenting his first season as the festival’s artistic director, this is churning up feelings of déjà vu.

title: Typhoon Ampil Approaches Japan, Disrupting Flights and Trains
description: Typhoon Ampil barreled toward Japan on Thursday packing strong winds and heavy rain, and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights and trains in and around Tokyo.

title: The Secret to Tom Wolfe’s Irresistible Snap, Crackle and Pop
description: There are certain writers you should never read before you yourself sit down to write, like P.G. Wodehouse and Tom Wolfe. For if you do, you will not be able to get their voices and rhythms out of your head, and you will have to confront the absolute certainty that you can’t pull off what they did. In Wolfe’s case you’ll find that you can’t quite replicate the raw energy of his prose: the fun; the snap, crackle, pop; the fuzzy effusions of new sociological categories — masters of the universe, social X-rays.

title: Mobility Issues? Balance Concerns? Try a Chair Workout.
description: In 2020, Aarthi Ravindran, then 23, was using a leg press machine at her gym when she suddenly felt an intense pain in her right knee. She was new to strength training and had tried to lift too much weight.

title: Yoko Ogawa Loves Finding Love at the Bookstore
description: What books are on your night stand?

title: 37 Square Feet That Show Brazil’s Racist Past
description: Ana Beatriz da Silva still remembers her first home: a tiny room behind the kitchen of a beachfront apartment in Rio de Janeiro, where her mother worked as a maid.

title: Lainey Wilson’s Exhausting (but Rewarding) Country Music Hustle
description: Lainey Wilson was born and raised in Baskin, La., population 210. Her dad is a fifth-generation farmer. “We grew corn, wheat, soybeans, oats. We did cotton back in the day,” she said proudly in a recent interview. While her ascent to country-music stardom means that her family’s finances are secure, she noted that lately there’s been a lack of rainfall in the northeast part of the state. “This year’s going to be pretty rough,” she added. “Farming has a lot of ups and downs. It’s very similar to the music business.”

title: Fall Fashion Is All About Refinement
And the Groom Wore Shorts
description: As soon as Willie Muse was invited to his cousin’s wedding in June on Cape Cod, he Googled what the “beach formal” dress code meant.

title: Judge John Hodgman on the Constitutionality of the ‘Pizza Tax’
description: Douglas writes: My family lives near a wonderful pizza place that doesn’t deliver. I don’t mind driving to get pizza, but I recently decided that the effort entitles me to eat a slice on the way home. My family objects very strongly to my “pizza tax.” (If you print this, call me “Spike.” I’ve always wanted to be called that.)

title: The Odd Duck of Antiguan Art, in His Ecstatic, Expressionist Glory
description: In “Frank Walter: To Capture a Soul,” a scavenger hunt of an exhibition at the Drawing Center in Manhattan, we find an aspect of so-called outsider art that is not easily conveyed in museums: compulsion.

title: ‘Jackpot!’ Review: Dystopia, Hollywood Style
description: In the near future, things are not very different. People wear the same clothes as we do, ride the bus to work, call each other on cellphones and stay in terrible Airbnbs run by hosts from hell. In the near future, everything is still expensive. And if you want to be an actor, you move to Los Angeles.

title: ‘Alien: Romulus’ Review: Go Ahead, Scream (No One Can Hear You)
description: Some movie sequels take a series in new directions, adding original ideas, new characters, different approaches and, at times, heft and myth. Other sequels are more like filler. They help plug the spaces between movies and keep the franchise’s brand in the public’s imagination, all while trying to make some cash. The newest “Alien” movie, “Alien: Romulus,” the seventh installment in this storied, apparently inexhaustible cycle of films, is perfectly adequate filler.

title: Embrace Your Summer Dad Bod. These Movies Show You the Way.
description: Ever since Elon Musk bought Twitter and somehow made the tailoring guru Derek Guy — better known by his handle @dieworkwear — an internet star, men’s wear has been the subject of more volcanically impassioned discussion online than ever. Where should the button on a suit jacket sit? Are brown shoes ever acceptable? Cargo shorts: yes or no? We are all critics of fit and silhouette now, pursing our lips in displeasure at every collar gap. But even in the final month of a brutally hot summer, one question remains underexplored: How should the thick-middled man present himself on the beach?

title: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
description: A six-bedroom, five-full-and-two-half-bath, 8,000-square-foot home built in the 1960s and updated in 2004, with a formal dining room and a sunken living room, a media room, a game room, an in-law suite, a finished walk-out basement with a sauna, an in-ground saltwater pool and a three-car attached garage, on two acres. Sheryl Epstein-Romano, Christie’s International Real Estate, 201-819-2999; christiesrealestate.com

title: It’s Too Late for Summer Now
description: I neglected to make plans for the summer. This obviously should have been worked out months ago. According to one market research firm, 56 percent of Americans surveyed in May were planning to take a vacation this summer, despite overtourism and sky-high prices.

title: The Federal Child Tax Credit Allowed Some Parents to Go It Alone
description: A temporary financial benefit for parents during the pandemic helped low-income families stay in their homes. But it also had the effect of allowing mothers to move on from unwanted partners, a new study shows.

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,100-square-foot apartment with stone countertops, a garbage disposal, an en suite bath with limestone and marble, radiant heat bathroom floors, zoned central air-conditioning and a washer/dryer, on the fifth floor of a 21-story doorman building from 2023 with a live-in super, basement storage cages, a gym, a children’s playroom, an art room, music and recording studios, a pet washing station and a roof deck. Doron Zwickel and Caleb Nickels, Core NYC, 917-400-4404; corenyc.com

title: Want to See Coral Reefs Grow? Freeze Them.
description: Since 2018, my lab has transplanted hundreds of coral specimens to reefs in Florida to study what makes them grow. We have albums of photos documenting their lives, starting from branches no bigger than your finger to beautiful treelike adults as big as beach balls.

title: U.S. Unveils Price Limits for 10 Costly or Common Medications
description: The Biden administration on Thursday unveiled the results of landmark drug price negotiations between Medicare and pharmaceutical companies, allowing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris to cast themselves as confronting the drug industry on behalf of older Americans at a critical moment in the presidential campaign.

title: Has RFK Jr.’s Moment Passed?
description: For much of the 2024 presidential election, it felt like there were pretty ideal conditions for a third-party candidate. Republicans and Democrats had both lined up behind broadly unpopular — and familiar — candidates. In the spring, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was polling at 10 percent in The New York Times/Siena College survey of battleground states, and sustained interest in his candidacy was enough to raise alarm among his major-party rivals.

title: The Anchovy Renaissance Is Here
description: Anchovies can help make plant-forward eating more delicious and appealing, argues Christopher Beckman, an archaeologist-turned-anchovy-lover. He is the author of “A Twist in the Tail: How the Humble Anchovy Flavored Western Cuisine,” and he makes the case for why we should all embrace the small, oily fish.

title: WCBS Had a Dramatic Start. Now It’s Coming to an End.
description: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at the history of WCBS, the all-news station. We’ll also look at Justice Juan Merchan’s third rejection of Donald Trump’s move for him to recuse himself from Trump’s case.

title: Democrats Are Missing Out on a Big Opportunity on Abortion Rights
description: Protecting reproductive rights is one of Democrats’ strongest issues, and their ability to capitalize on it may decide a tight election. Chances are even better now with Kamala Harris, a candidate known for her unapologetic positions on the issue, at the top of the ticket.

title: The Intensification of JD Vance
description: Since JD Vance got more political and decided to run for office, making sense of exactly the kind of politician he is and will be has been a challenge. There are different modes of Mr. Vance as a public figure. He has been the populist intellectual who works with Elizabeth Warren and also the tech podcast right-winger who talks about America as being in the “late republican period.” He can be the lawyerly professional on a Sunday show or the guy, when asked what makes him happy, who talks about anger.

title: Tim Walz’s Bumpy Road to Gun Control
description: In a tight primary for governor in 2018, Tim Walz, then a congressman from a conservative pro-gun district in Minnesota, was rebuked for his A ratings from the National Rifle Association. After a school shooting in Parkland, Fla., he went on the offensive.

title: 36 Hours in Provincetown, Mass.
description: P-town offers overlapping identities: one of America’s oldest art colonies, nature preserve, thriving L.G.B.T.Q. resort and historic Portuguese fishing village.

title: San Francisco Moves to Lead Fight Against Deepfake Nudes
description: Like many parents, Yvonne Meré was deeply disturbed when she read about a frightening new trend.

title: I Wrote ‘Friday Night Lights.’ Here’s Why Coach Tim Walz Stands Apart.
description: Before Gov. Tim Walz became the most famous person in America to coach high school football, there was Eric Taylor.

title: A Three-Bedroom House in the Bay Area for Under $1 Million? Here Were Their Options.
description: After six years in the desert of Palm Springs, a retired couple headed north in search of new construction in Sonoma County.

title: A Sunny New Restaurant in a Parisian Train Station
description: “I’m So Happy You Are Here: Japanese Women Photographers from the 1950s to Now,” a new book published by Aperture, features wide-ranging portfolios by 25 photographers. As Pauline Vermare, a co-editor of the book, writes in her introductory essay, the primary focus of the women showcased in the book “has been, and remains, to find the means to be independent and represent their own experiences and views of the world.” Among the works included are those by the 77-year-old photographer Miyako Ishiuchi, who co-founded a photography magazine, main, in 1996. The book contains photos from “Yokosuka Story,” a 1970s series focusing on her hometown, the location of a major U.S. Navy base, and a still-life of a lipstick, part of her “Mother’s” (2000-2005) series, for which she photographed her deceased mother’s possessions. One of the youngest photographers in the book, Momo Okabe, 43, trains her lens on her own body and those of her friends, capturing both everyday experiences and life-changing events such as gender-affirming surgery and pregnancy. From photojournalism to works of collage, the book, as its introduction states, “lays the groundwork for understanding the enormity of what has been overlooked.” “I’m So Happy You Are Here” is out on Sept. 17, $75, aperture.org.

title: Nevada Senate Race Now Favors Democrat, Report Says
description: Senator Jacky Rosen of Nevada, a Democrat seeking re-election to her seat for the first time, is pulling ahead of her Republican challenger, Sam Brown, in a race that was once considered a feasible pickup for the G.O.P., according to several polls released this week.

title: Half Their Land Burned in a Decade: The California Counties Constantly on Fire
description: Park fire became California’s fourth largest this month. It erupted in a part of the state that is increasingly covered with the scars of wildfires.

title: Seeking Calm, Columbia University Asks a Doctor to Lead
description: Dr. Katrina A. Armstrong was out of sorts.

title: Ukraine Is Poking the Russian Bear
description: Here’s one way to think through the importance of the news stories that flood our lives: Which ones will historians still be talking about in 50 years? Are there any that they’ll be talking about in 100?

title: A Mob Attack on a Toppled Party Shows Bangladesh’s Dangerous Vacuum
description: The tables had turned: Yesterday’s victims of brutal suppression were today’s perpetrators of brutal revenge.

title: Canceling Memberships Is a Pain. New Biden Administration Rules Aim to Make It Easier.
description: A set of policies proposed by the Biden administration this week could make it easier for consumers to cancel subscriptions, speak to customer service agents, get flight refunds and more.

title: 5.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Taiwan
description: A 5.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the east coast of Taiwan on Thursday, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,154
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: All Eyes on Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, and Kennedy Explores a Cabinet Job
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The Connections Companion No. 432
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: A Controversial Crackdown on Homeless Encampments
description: In the weeks since a landmark Supreme Court ruling opened the door for cities and states to crack down on homeless encampments, California — the state with the largest homeless population — has taken some of the nation’s most sweeping actions against them.

title: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 12 Years in Prison on Treason Charges
description: A court in Russia sentenced a dual citizen of Russia and the United States on Thursday to 12 years in prison on accusations that she committed treason by donating money — about $50 — for Ukraine’s armed forces.

title: A Catastrophic Civil War in Sudan
description: After more than a year of civil war, the toll in Sudan is heartbreaking: thousands killed, millions scattered and cities besieged or destroyed across a vast nation three times as large as France. Much of the capital lies in rubble. This month, international officials declared that part of Sudan was in a famine. At least 100 people die of hunger every day.

title: Ukraine Captures Russian Town, Zelensky Says
description: Ukrainian troops took full control of the Russian town of Sudzha, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Thursday, in what would be Ukraine’s first capture of a Russian urban center since its troops launched a surprise attack into the country 10 days ago.

title: ‘Caligula: The Ultimate Cut’ Review: The Emperor’s New Clothes
description: Based on conventional metrics like, say, tastefulness or storytelling integrity, the 1980 movie “Caligula” is not good. It is, however, completely nuts. And that has turned out to be more than enough to fuel an obsessive cult over the decades.

title: ‘Close to You’ Review: Clumsy Overtures of Support
description: The title of the diffuse drama “Close to You” refers to a sweet nothing murmured between old friends on a wintry Canadian lakeshore. Sam (Elliot Page), visiting his hometown for his father’s birthday, takes a walk with his former confidante, Katherine (a stirring Hillary Baack). Katherine expresses that she is glad to be in Sam’s proximity after nearly two decades. He confesses that he was once in love with her.

title: ‘The Greatest Surf Movie in the Universe’ Review: Humongously Bad
description: Jeff Spicoli, the surfing-obsessed truant portrayed memorably by Sean Penn in “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” (1982), may have been an airhead, but he had a vocabulary. Things he enjoyed were “gnarly” or “humongous.”

title: ‘In the Rearview’ Review: Shuttling Ukrainians to Safety
description: Maciek Hamela’s perceptive documentary “In the Rearview” seats us in a van shuttling groups of Ukrainians from conflict areas to safety. That simple viewpoint, along with roadside scenes of pickups and drop-offs, captures the moments when ordinary life ended and the deadly chaos of the Russian invasion began.

title: ‘The Good Half’ Review: Only Half Good
description: “Grief turns out to be a place none of us know until we reach it,” Joan Didion once wrote. In “The Good Half,” that place is Cleveland, where 20-somethings with names like Renn, Leigh and Zoey frequent karaoke bars and banter about movies.

title: Walmart Sees Higher Sales From Picky Shoppers
description: The state of the economy can be confusing. Consumers, stung by high inflation for two years and navigating a slowing job market, are still spending at a decent clip — but on store-brand soda, not new refrigerators. That puts Walmart, the company that made low prices a mantra, in a good position.

title: The Economy Moves to Center Stage in the Election
description: As Vice President Kamala Harris hits the road to start spelling out her economic agenda, she could point to recent progress in the inflation fight that has hounded the Biden administration and Democrats for the past two years.

title: He Still Thought He Could Win: Inside Biden’s Decision to Drop Out
description: In the end, he was alone.

title: America Can’t Produce the Weapons It Needs for the Future. This Could Help.
description: Australia, the United States and Britain have agreed to exempt each other from a vast array of export controls for defense technology, making it easier to trade and collaborate on weapons development and production.

title: Stocks Rise for Sixth Day as Retail Sales Ease Concerns About Economy
description: Retail sales in July came in above expectations, the government reported on Thursday, painting an optimistic picture of consumer spending that could ease concerns about the strength of the economy.

title: Tim Walz and JD Vance Agree to Vice-Presidential Debate
description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio have agreed to participate in at least one vice-presidential debate this fall, with both candidates accepting an invitation from CBS News to face off on Oct. 1.

title: 2026 Prices for Drugs That Are Subject to Negotiations
description: The Biden administration on Thursday announced the results of negotiations between Medicare and pharmaceutical companies over the prices of 10 costly or common medications. The new prices, which will take effect in 2026, are the maximum Medicare Part D plans and patients will pay for a one-month supply.

title: Matthew Perry’s Assistant and Doctors Charged With Getting Him Ketamine
description: Matthew Perry’s personal assistant, two doctors and two others have been indicted and charged with providing the ketamine that caused the death of Mr. Perry, a star on the television show “Friends,” the authorities said on Thursday.

title: N.J. Transit Says Thank You, and Sorry, With a Week of Free Rides
description: After struggling to provide reliable service to commuters this spring and summer, New Jersey Transit is giving its customers free rides for a week, Gov. Philip D. Murphy announced on Thursday.

title: Amid Heightened Security, Taylor Swift Returns to the Stage in London
description: When Taylor Swift canceled three concerts in Vienna last week after officials there foiled a terrorist plot, Swifties soon expressed fears about the pop star’s next shows, in London.

title: ‘Red Island’ Review: Madagascar Is Shifting Beneath Their Feet
description: The striking rusty color that gives Madagascar the nickname the “great red island” comes from the rich iron content in its soil. The drama “Red Island” — about a white French boy from a military family living there in the early 1970s — suggests that a fair amount of blood has seeped into the earth, too. The boy is just 10 but he grasps more than other kids might because his experiences are filtered through the life of the French filmmaker Robin Campillo.

title: On Anniversary of Taliban Takeover, Glee, Mourning and an Embrace of Jihad
description: The parade of cars rolled through Kabul from morning until night, clogging the streets in end-to-end traffic. Crowds of Taliban and their supporters lined the routes, chanting “God is great!” and “Long live the mujahedeen!” One truck dragged an American flag, a red X drawn across its stars and stripes.

title: From Here to Eternity, a Choreographer Sinks Into the Sea
description: [Update: “Oceanic Feeling” has been postponed until Sept. 2 at 6 p.m.]

title: For the Man Who Plays Lafayette, It’s a Marquis Event
description: On a recent sultry Monday, Mark Schneider pulled up to a stable in Williamsburg, Va., ready to get back to the grind, 18th-century style.

title: Beware the Toxic and Explosive Blue Backpack This Termite Carries
description: The video shows a termite worker under attack. Three enemies of another species scramble over its body, limbs dancing and mandibles closing. Suddenly, the attacked worker’s back erupts and caustic foam pours from its body. It will die, but this fountain of toxic material may save its nestmates from the invaders.

title: This Classic Corn Chowder Is Quite Resourceful
description: One of my favorite things my grandma taught me was mottainai, the Japanese philosophy of being resourceful and not wasting anything that might be useful. She’d save strips of pretty wrapping paper and yarn scraps to make beautiful collages; in the kitchen, the smallest pieces of leftover salmon or beef would be made into onigiri or ochazuke. Mottainai is just as much about being creative as it is about being careful.

title: Sydney Lemmon Puts the Twisted Humanity Behind Tech on Broadway
description: Jane is a young professional living in the Bay Area whom you might find at SoulCycle. The actor Sydney Lemmon has taken that description of her character in “Job” with a grain of salt.

title: Judge Finds Flaws in New York City’s Cannabis Enforcement Efforts
description: A state judge has ordered New York City to allow a convenience store in Queens to reopen after it was accused of selling cannabis illegally, a decision that could significantly affect the city’s effort to wipe out thousands of unlicensed sellers.

title: Menendez Will Be Replaced in Senate by Murphy Loyalist
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey on Friday named George Helmy, his former chief of staff, to serve out the remainder of the term of Senator Robert Menendez, who was convicted of corruption and is stepping down next week.

title: Wind Beat Coal Two Months in a Row for U.S. Electricity Generation
description: Wind turbines generated more electricity than coal-burning power plants across the United States in March and April, outstripping the dirtiest fuel for two consecutive months for the first time, according to the Energy Information Administration.

title: Macron Honors African Soldiers Who Helped Liberate France in World War II
description: President Emmanuel Macron came to the south of France on Thursday to honor a second landing, the less white and more forgotten one, in which over 350,000 Allied troops stormed ashore in Provence and went on to liberate towns including Marseille and Toulon, before moving northward.

title: Medic’s Killing Fuels Protests and Walkouts in India
description: After a long shift last Thursday, a junior doctor went to sleep in a seminar room at the Kolkata hospital where she worked. The next morning, her colleagues found her dead, her body showing signs of rape and extreme physical brutality.

title: How Did Mpox Become a Global Emergency? What’s Next?
description: Faced once again with a rapidly spreading epidemic of mpox, the World Health Organization on Wednesday declared a global health emergency. The last time the W.H.O. made that call was in 2022, when the disease was still called monkeypox.

title: An Alternative to the Pap Smear Is Here, No Speculum Required
description: For some women, getting a Pap smear is hell.

title: Seth Bloom, 49, Clown Who Brought Laughter to the Rubble of War, Dies
description: Seth Bloom, a blue-haired clown and physical comedy virtuoso who helped outreach organizations in Afghanistan and other remote places stage circuses that roused smiles from children while also teaching them important life skills, like how to avoid land mines, died on Aug. 2 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 49.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in August
description: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of the most promising new titles in August. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

title: Learning From Success With Homeless Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: New Israeli Settlement in West Bank Would Encroach on World Heritage Site, Activists Say
description: A new Israeli settlement planned for construction in the occupied West Bank will encroach on Palestinian land recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage site, Israeli peace activists say.

title: Harvard Names Conservative Legal Scholar as Permanent Provost
description: Harvard University appointed on Thursday a conservative legal scholar as provost, the university’s second-highest leadership position. The move comes as Harvard faces a congressional investigation into campus antisemitism while bracing for a new season of student protests against the Israel-Hamas war.

title: Judge Who Had Teenager Handcuffed on Field Trip Is Temporarily Removed From Docket
description: A District Court judge in Detroit who ordered a teenager visiting his courtroom to be handcuffed after he caught her sleeping has temporarily been removed from hearing cases, the court’s chief judge said on Thursday.

title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia Reveals a Dramatic Shift
description: Ukraine’s incursion into a sliver of Russia is likely to make it harder for Moscow to mount a major renewed offensive in Ukraine’s east and is the kind of surprise operation that could eventually impose real costs on the Kremlin, according to U.S. officials.

title: What Is a Salad, Anyway?
description: “I’ll bring salad!” the text read. I’d invited a friend over for dinner and was relieved by the gesture. One less thing to prepare.

title: Trump Seeks to Delay His Sentencing Until After the Election
description: Former President Donald J. Trump is seeking to delay his criminal sentencing in Manhattan until after the presidential election, imploring the judge overseeing the case to allow him additional time to challenge his conviction.

title: Burning Man Has Sold Out Since 2011. Why Not This Year?
description: Burning Man, the Nevada desert festival that routinely sells out tickets, is set to return this month, and ticket sales have slumped for the first time in years.

title: Prosecutors Accuse Argentina’s Former President of Beating First Lady
description: Argentine prosecutors on Wednesday accused Alberto Fernández, Argentina’s former president who left office in December, of domestic violence after images showed his partner at the time, the former first lady, with a black eye.

title: What to Know About the Latest Social Security Number Breach
description: The details are murky. In April, Hackmanac, a cybersecurity company, posted on X that about 2.9 billion records of personal data were for sale, from people in the United States, Canada and Britain. The data was supposedly stolen from National Public Data, a company that does background checks.

title: Democrats Lean Into Liberty and the Language of Republicans
description: In Michigan, Vice President Kamala Harris declared that Americans should be free to make personal decisions — without having “their government telling them what to do.”

title: Harris Plans to Ban Grocery ‘Price Gouging.’ What Does the Evidence Say?
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s economic agenda for her presidential campaign features an argument that blames corporate price gouging for high grocery prices.

title: Young Humpback Whale Spotted in Boston Harbor
description: A juvenile humpback whale has been splashing in Boston Harbor. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority warned that ferry service could be delayed because of the whale’s presence.

title: Unusual Origin Found for Asteroid That Killed the Dinosaurs
